   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Croatia</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       country in Southeast Europe
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Croatia&amp;params=45_10_N_15_30_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">45°10′N</span> <span class="longitude">15°30′E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">45.167°N 15.500°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">45.167; 15.500</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

          </div></th>

           <div style="text-align:center;line-height:1.15em;">
            Location of&nbsp;Croatia&nbsp;(dark green)
            <p style="text-align:left;margin-left:1.2ex;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:1.15em;">–&nbsp;in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a>&nbsp;(green &amp;&nbsp;dark grey)<br>–&nbsp;in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>&nbsp;(green)</p>
           </div>
          </div></td>
        </tr>

      <p><b>Croatia</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'k' in 'kind'">k</span><span title="'r' in 'rye'">r</span><span title="/oʊ/: 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">ʃ</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Croatia.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/24/En-us-Croatia.ogg" class="internal" title="En-us-Croatia.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span>, <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling">kroh-<span style="font-size:90%">AY</span>-shə</i></a>; <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">Hrvatska</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian" title="Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian">[xř̩ʋaːtskaː]</a></span>), officially the <b>Republic of Croatia</b> (Croatian: <i lang="hr">Republika Hrvatska</i>, <span style="font-size:85%;">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Hr-Republika_Hrvatska.oga" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/33/Hr-Republika_Hrvatska.oga" class="internal" title="Hr-Republika Hrvatska.oga">listen</a></span></span>)</span>),<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[e]</a></sup> is a country at the crossroads of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>. It borders <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> to the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> to the southeast, and shares a <a href="/wiki/Maritime_boundary" title="Maritime boundary">maritime border</a> with <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> to the west and southwest. Its capital and largest city, <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>, forms one of the country's <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Croatia" title="Administrative divisions of Croatia">primary subdivisions</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">twenty counties</a>. Croatia has 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles) and a population of 4.07&nbsp;million. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">Croats</a> arrived in the 6th century and organised the territory into <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Croatia" title="Duchy of Croatia">two duchies</a> by the 9th century. Croatia was first internationally recognised as independent on 7 June 879 during the reign of Duke <a href="/wiki/Branimir_of_Croatia" title="Branimir of Croatia">Branimir</a>. <a href="/wiki/Tomislav_of_Croatia" title="Tomislav of Croatia">Tomislav</a> became the first king by 925, elevating Croatia to the status of a <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">kingdom</a>. During the succession crisis after the Trpimirović dynasty ended, Croatia <a href="/wiki/Croatia_in_personal_union_with_Hungary" title="Croatia in personal union with Hungary">entered</a> a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> with <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Hungary</a> in 1102. In 1527, faced with <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_War" title="Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War">Ottoman conquest</a>, the Croatian Parliament elected <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor">Ferdinand I of Austria</a> to the Croatian throne. In October 1918, the <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs" title="State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs">State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs</a>, independent from Austria-Hungary, was proclaimed in Zagreb, and in December 1918, <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia" title="Creation of Yugoslavia">merged</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a>. Following the Axis <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Yugoslavia" title="Invasion of Yugoslavia">invasion of Yugoslavia</a> in April 1941, most of Croatia was incorporated into a Nazi installed puppet state, the <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a>. A <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Partisans" title="Croatian Partisans">resistance movement</a> led to the creation of the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia" title="Socialist Republic of Croatia">Socialist Republic of Croatia</a>, which after the war became a founding member and constituent of the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a>. On 25 June 1991, Croatia <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">declared independence</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">War of Independence</a> was fought for four years following the declaration. </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a>, Croatia is a <a href="/wiki/Republic" title="Republic">republic</a> governed under a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>. It is a member of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a>, and a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>. An active participant in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping" title="United Nations peacekeeping">United Nations peacekeeping</a>, Croatia has contributed troops to the <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">International Security Assistance Force</a> and took a nonpermanent seat on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> for the 2008–2009 term. Since 2000, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Croatia" title="Government of Croatia">Croatian government</a> has invested in infrastructure, especially <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Croatia" title="Transport in Croatia">transport routes and facilities</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_corridors" title="Pan-European corridors">Pan-European corridors</a>. </p>
      <p>Croatia is classified by the World Bank as a <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_high-income_economy" title="World Bank high-income economy">high-income</a> economy and ranks very high on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">Service</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secondary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Secondary sector of the economy">industrial sectors</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a> dominate the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Croatia" title="Economy of Croatia">economy</a>, respectively. <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">Tourism</a> is a significant source of revenue, with Croatia ranked among the 20 most popular tourist destinations. The state controls a part of the economy, with substantial government expenditure. The European Union is Croatia's most important <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">trading partner</a>. Croatia provides <a href="/wiki/Welfare" title="Welfare">social security</a>, <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Croatia" title="Healthcare in Croatia">universal health care</a>, and tuition-free <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Croatia" title="Education in Croatia">primary and secondary education</a> while supporting <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia" title="Culture of Croatia">culture</a> through public institutions and corporate investments in <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Croatia" title="Mass media in Croatia">media</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_literature" title="Croatian literature">publishing</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_the_Croats_and_Croatia" title="Names of the Croats and Croatia">Names of the Croats and Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tanais_Tablet_B.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/140px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png" decoding="async" width="140" height="201" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/210px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Tanais_Tablet_B.png/280px-Tanais_Tablet_B.png 2x" data-file-width="414" data-file-height="595"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tanais_Tablet_B.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Tanais_Tablets" title="Tanais Tablets">Tanais Tablet B</a> containing the word Χοροάθος (<i>Khoroáthos</i>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Name_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Name of Croatia">name of Croatia</a> derives from <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">Medieval Latin</a> <i>Croātia</i>. Itself a derivation of <a href="/wiki/North-West_Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="North-West Slavic">North-West Slavic</a> <i>*Xrovat-</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Liquid_metathesis" class="mw-redirect" title="Liquid metathesis">liquid metathesis</a> from Common Slavic period <i>*Xorvat</i>, from proposed <a href="/wiki/Proto-Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Slavic">Proto-Slavic</a> <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/x%D1%8Arvat%D1%8A" class="extiw" title="wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/xъrvatъ">*Xъrvátъ</a></i> which possibly comes from <a href="/wiki/Old_Persian" title="Old Persian">Old Persian</a> <i>*xaraxwat-</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Gluhak-1993_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gluhak-1993-16">[11]</a></sup> the root word being a 3rd-century <a href="/wiki/Scytho-Sarmatian" class="mw-redirect" title="Scytho-Sarmatian">Scytho-Sarmatian</a> form attested in the <a href="/wiki/Tanais_Tablets" title="Tanais Tablets">Tanais Tablets</a> as Χοροάθος (<i>Khoroáthos</i>, alternate forms comprise <i>Khoróatos</i> and <i>Khoroúathos</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Gluhak-1993_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gluhak-1993-16">[11]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The origin of the name is uncertain but is thought to be a <a href="/wiki/Gothic_language" title="Gothic language">Gothic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a> term assigned to a <a href="/wiki/Slavic_tribe" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic tribe">Slavic tribe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-KU-Greenberg_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KU-Greenberg-17">[12]</a></sup> The oldest preserved record of the Croatian <a href="/wiki/Ethnonym" title="Ethnonym">ethnonym</a> <i>*xъrvatъ</i> is of the variable stem, attested in the <a href="/wiki/Ba%C5%A1ka_tablet" title="Baška tablet">Baška tablet</a> in <a href="/wiki/Style_(manner_of_address)" class="mw-redirect" title="Style (manner of address)">style</a> <i>zvъnъmirъ kralъ xrъvatъskъ</i> ("<a href="/wiki/Dmitar_Zvonimir" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitar Zvonimir">Zvonimir</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_king" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian king">Croatian king</a>").<sup id="cite_ref-Fučić-1971_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fučić-1971-18">[13]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The first attestation of the Latin term is attributed to a charter of Duke <a href="/wiki/Trpimir" class="mw-redirect" title="Trpimir">Trpimir</a> from the year 852. The original is lost, and just a 1568 copy is preserved, leading to doubts over the authenticity of the claim.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić200727_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić200727-19">[14]</a></sup> Although was archaeologically confirmed that the ethnonym <i>Croatorum</i> is mentioned in a church inscription found in <a href="/wiki/Bija%C4%87i" title="Bijaći">Bijaći</a> near <a href="/wiki/Trogir" title="Trogir">Trogir</a> dated to the end of the 8th or early 9th century,<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[15]</a></sup> the presumably oldest preserved stone <a href="/wiki/Inscription" class="mw-redirect" title="Inscription">inscription</a> is the 9th-century <a href="/wiki/Branimir_Inscription" class="mw-redirect" title="Branimir Inscription">Branimir Inscription</a> found near <a href="/wiki/Benkovac" title="Benkovac">Benkovac</a>, where Duke <a href="/wiki/Branimir_of_Croatia" title="Branimir of Croatia">Branimir</a> is styled <i>Dux Cruatorvm</i>. It is not believed to be dated accurately but is likely to be from 879 to 892, during Branimir's rule.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198-21">[16]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Croatia" title="History of Croatia">History of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Prehistoric Croatia">Prehistoric Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The area known as Croatia today was inhabited throughout the <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Prehistoric period">prehistoric period</a>. Fossils of <a href="/wiki/Neanderthals" class="mw-redirect" title="Neanderthals">Neanderthals</a> dating to the middle <a href="/wiki/Palaeolithic" class="mw-redirect" title="Palaeolithic">Palaeolithic</a> period have been unearthed in northern Croatia, with the most famous and the best presented site in <a href="/wiki/Krapina" title="Krapina">Krapina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[17]</a></sup> Remnants of several <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a> cultures were found in all regions of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[18]</a></sup> The largest proportion of the sites is in the river valleys of northern Croatia, and the most significant cultures whose presence was discovered include <a href="/wiki/Baden_culture" title="Baden culture">Baden</a>, <a href="/wiki/Star%C4%8Devo_culture" title="Starčevo culture">Starčevo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vu%C4%8Dedol_culture" title="Vučedol culture">Vučedol cultures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[20]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a> left traces of the early Illyrian <a href="/wiki/Hallstatt_culture" title="Hallstatt culture">Hallstatt culture</a> and the Celtic <a href="/wiki/La_T%C3%A8ne_culture" title="La Tène culture">La Tène culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[21]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia_(Roman_province)" title="Dalmatia (Roman province)">Dalmatia (Roman province)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pannonia_(Roman_province)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pannonia (Roman province)">Pannonia (Roman province)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG/220px-Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG/330px-Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG/440px-Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="576"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zagreb_Apoxyomenos_-_figure.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Croatian_Apoxyomenos" title="Croatian Apoxyomenos">Croatian Apoxyomenos</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Ancient Greek</a> statue, 2nd or 1st century BC
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Much later, the region was settled by <a href="/wiki/Illyrians" title="Illyrians">Illyrians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liburnians" title="Liburnians">Liburnians</a>, while the first Greek colonies were established on the islands of <a href="/wiki/Hvar" title="Hvar">Hvar</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[22]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kor%C4%8Dula" title="Korčula">Korčula</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vis_(island)" title="Vis (island)">Vis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[23]</a></sup> In 9&nbsp;AD, the territory of today's Croatia became part of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>. Emperor <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a> was native to the region, and he had a large palace built in <a href="/wiki/Split,_Croatia" title="Split, Croatia">Split</a>, to which he retired after his abdication in AD 305.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[24]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 5th century, the <a href="/wiki/Last_de_jure_Western_Roman_Emperor" class="mw-redirect" title="Last de jure Western Roman Emperor">last de jure Western Roman Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Julius_Nepos" title="Julius Nepos">Julius Nepos</a> ruled his small realm from the palace after fleeing Italy in 475.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[25]</a></sup> The period ends with <a href="/wiki/Avars_(Carpathians)" class="mw-redirect" title="Avars (Carpathians)">Avar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croat" class="mw-redirect" title="Croat">Croat</a> invasions in the first half of the 7th century and the destruction of almost all Roman towns. Roman survivors retreated to more favourable sites on the coast, islands, and mountains. The city of <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">Dubrovnik</a> was founded by such survivors from <a href="/wiki/Epidaurum" title="Epidaurum">Epidaurum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AAPatton_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AAPatton-31">[26]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_studies_on_Croats" title="Genetic studies on Croats">Genetic studies on Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Origin_hypotheses_of_the_Croats" title="Origin hypotheses of the Croats">Origin hypotheses of the Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_Croats" title="White Croats">White Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_Croatia" title="White Croatia">White Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Croatia" title="Duchy of Croatia">Duchy of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(1102%E2%80%931526)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Croatia (1102–1526)">Kingdom of Croatia (1102–1526)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Republic of Ragusa</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Balkans925.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/220px-Balkans925.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/330px-Balkans925.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Balkans925.png/440px-Balkans925.png 2x" data-file-width="472" data-file-height="605"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Balkans925.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(925%E2%80%931102)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)">Kingdom of Croatia</a> c.&nbsp;925, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/King_Tomislav" class="mw-redirect" title="King Tomislav">King Tomislav</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethnogenesis" title="Ethnogenesis">ethnogenesis</a> of Croats is uncertain, and there are several competing theories, Slavic and Iranian being the most frequently put forward. The most widely accepted of these, the Slavic theory, proposes migration of <a href="/wiki/White_Croats" title="White Croats">White Croats</a> from <a href="/wiki/White_Croatia" title="White Croatia">White Croatia</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Period" title="Migration Period">Migration Period</a>. Conversely, the Iranian theory proposes <a href="/wiki/Iranian_peoples" title="Iranian peoples">Iranian</a> origin, based on <a href="/wiki/Tanais_Tablets" title="Tanais Tablets">Tanais Tablets</a> containing <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> inscriptions of given names <i>Χορούαθος</i>, <i>Χοροάθος</i>, and <i>Χορόαθος</i> (Khoroúathos, Khoroáthos, and Khoróathos) and their interpretation as <a href="/wiki/Anthroponym" class="mw-redirect" title="Anthroponym">anthroponyms</a> of Croatian people.<sup id="cite_ref-Nikšić-Heršak_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nikšić-Heršak-32">[27]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the work <i><a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">De Administrando Imperio</a></i> written by the 10th-century Byzantine Emperor <a href="/wiki/Constantine_VII" title="Constantine VII">Constantine VII</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">Croats</a> had arrived in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_province_of_Dalmatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman province of Dalmatia">Roman province of Dalmatia</a> in the first half of the 7th century after they defeated the <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Avars" title="Pannonian Avars">Avars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein199913_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein199913-34">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[30]</a></sup> However, that claim is disputed, and competing hypotheses date the event between the 6th and the 9th centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007249–293_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007249–293-36">[31]</a></sup> Eventually, a <a href="/wiki/Dukedom_(administrative_division)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dukedom (administrative division)">dukedom</a> was formed, <a href="/wiki/Duchy_of_Croatia" title="Duchy of Croatia">Duchy of Croatia</a>, ruled by <a href="/wiki/Borna_(duke)" title="Borna (duke)">Borna</a>, as attested by chronicles of <a href="/wiki/Einhard" title="Einhard">Einhard</a> starting in 818. The record represents the first document of Croatian realms, <a href="/wiki/Vassal_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Vassal states">vassal states</a> of <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a> at the time.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007157–160_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007157–160-37">[32]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Frankish overlordship ended during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Mislav_of_Croatia" title="Mislav of Croatia">Mislav</a> two decades later.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007169–170_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007169–170-38">[33]</a></sup> According to Constantine VII <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">Christianization</a> of Croats began in the 7th century, but the claim is disputed, and generally, Christianization is associated with the 9th century.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[34]</a></sup> The first native Croatian ruler recognised by the Pope was Duke Branimir, who received papal recognition from <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_VIII" title="Pope John VIII">Pope John VIII</a> on 7 June 879.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMužić2007195–198-21">[16]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Oton_Ivekovic,_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg/220px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg/330px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg/440px-Oton_Ivekovic%2C_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1098" data-file-height="682"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Oton_Ivekovic,_Krunidba_kralja_Tomislava.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Coronation of <a href="/wiki/King_Tomislav" class="mw-redirect" title="King Tomislav">King Tomislav</a> by <a href="/wiki/Oton_Ivekovi%C4%87" title="Oton Iveković">Oton Iveković</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tomislav_of_Croatia" title="Tomislav of Croatia">Tomislav</a> was the first <a href="/wiki/King_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="King of Croatia">king of Croatia</a>, styled as such in a letter of <a href="/wiki/Pope_John_X" title="Pope John X">Pope John X</a> in 925. Tomislav defeated Hungarian and <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_invasions" class="mw-redirect" title="Bulgarian invasions">Bulgarian invasions</a>, spreading the influence of Croatian kings.<sup id="cite_ref-Posavec_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Posavec-40">[35]</a></sup> The medieval Croatian kingdom reached its peak in the 11th century during the reigns of <a href="/wiki/Petar_Kre%C5%A1imir_IV" class="mw-redirect" title="Petar Krešimir IV">Petar Krešimir IV</a> (1058–1074) and <a href="/wiki/Dmitar_Zvonimir" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitar Zvonimir">Dmitar Zvonimir</a> (1075–1089).<sup id="cite_ref-Margetić_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Margetić-41">[36]</a></sup> When <a href="/wiki/Stephen_II_of_Croatia" title="Stephen II of Croatia">Stjepan II</a> died in 1091, ending the <a href="/wiki/Trpimirovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Trpimirović">Trpimirović</a> dynasty, Dmitar Zvonimir's brother-in-law <a href="/wiki/Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary" title="Ladislaus I of Hungary">Ladislaus I of Hungary</a> claimed the Croatian crown. This led to a <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gvozd_Mountain" title="Battle of Gvozd Mountain">war</a> and <a href="/wiki/Personal_union_of_Croatia_and_Hungary" class="mw-redirect" title="Personal union of Croatia and Hungary">personal union of Croatia and Hungary</a> in 1102 under <a href="/wiki/Coloman,_King_of_Hungary" title="Coloman, King of Hungary">Coloman</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-42">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For the next four centuries, the Kingdom of Croatia was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Sabor" class="mw-redirect" title="Sabor">Sabor</a> (parliament) and a <a href="/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia" title="Ban of Croatia">ban</a> (viceroy) appointed by the king.<sup id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-43">[38]</a></sup> This period saw the rise of influential nobility such as the <a href="/wiki/Frankopan" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankopan">Frankopan</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ubi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Šubić">Šubić</a> families to prominence, and ultimately numerous Bans from the two families.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFont200517_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFont200517-44">[39]</a></sup> There was an increasing threat of <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> conquest and a struggle against the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a> for control of coastal areas. The Venetians controlled most of Dalmatia by 1428, except the <a href="/wiki/City-state_of_Dubrovnik" class="mw-redirect" title="City-state of Dubrovnik">city-state of Dubrovnik</a>, which became independent. <a href="/wiki/Hundred_Years%27_Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_War" title="Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War">Ottoman conquests</a> led to the 1493 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Krbava_field" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of Krbava field">Battle of Krbava field</a> and the 1526 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moh%C3%A1cs" title="Battle of Mohács">Battle of Mohács</a>, both ending in decisive Ottoman victories. King <a href="/wiki/Louis_II_of_Hungary" title="Louis II of Hungary">Louis II</a> died at Mohács, and in 1527, the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament_met_in_Cetin" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Parliament met in Cetin">Croatian Parliament met in Cetin</a> and chose Ferdinand I of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Habsburg" title="House of Habsburg">House of Habsburg</a> as the new ruler of Croatia, under the condition that he protects Croatia against the Ottoman Empire while respecting its political rights.<sup id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-43">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-45">[40]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Personal_union_with_Hungary_.281102.29_and_Habsburg_Monarchy_.281527.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_union_with_Hungary_(1102)_and_Habsburg_Monarchy_(1527)">Personal union with Hungary (1102) and Habsburg Monarchy (1527)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)">Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_wars" title="Croatian–Ottoman wars">Croatian–Ottoman wars</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/220px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/330px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg/440px-Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2306" data-file-height="1663"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Johann_Peter_Krafft_005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Croatian <a href="/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia" title="Ban of Croatia">Ban</a> <a href="/wiki/Nikola_%C5%A0ubi%C4%87_Zrinski" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikola Šubić Zrinski">Nikola Šubić Zrinski</a> is honoured as a national hero for his defence of <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Szigetv%C3%A1r" title="Siege of Szigetvár">Szigetvár</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Invading_Ottoman_Turks" class="mw-redirect" title="Invading Ottoman Turks">invading Ottoman Turks</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the decisive Ottoman victories, Croatia was split into civilian and military territories, with the partition formed in 1538. The military territories would become known as the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Military_Frontier" title="Croatian Military Frontier">Croatian Military Frontier</a> and were under direct Habsburg control. Ottoman advances in Croatia continued until the 1593 <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Sisak" title="Battle of Sisak">Battle of Sisak</a>, the first decisive Ottoman defeat, and stabilisation of borders.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-45">[40]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">Great Turkish War</a> (1683–1698), <a href="/wiki/Slavonia" title="Slavonia">Slavonia</a> was regained, but western <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_(region)" title="Bosnia (region)">Bosnia</a>, which had been part of Croatia before the Ottoman conquest, remained outside Croatian control.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_45-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-45">[40]</a></sup> The present-day border between the two countries is a remnant of this outcome. <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>, the southern part of the border, was similarly defined by the <a href="/wiki/Cretan_War_(1645%E2%80%931669)" title="Cretan War (1645–1669)">Fifth</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Ottoman%E2%80%93Venetian_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Seventh Ottoman–Venetian Wars">Seventh Ottoman–Venetian Wars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELane1973409_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELane1973409-46">[41]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Ottoman_wars" title="Croatian–Ottoman wars">Ottoman wars</a> instigated large demographic changes. During the 16th century, Croats from western and northern <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_(region)" title="Bosnia (region)">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lika" title="Lika">Lika</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krbava" title="Krbava">Krbava</a>, the area between the rivers of <a href="/wiki/Una_(Sava)" title="Una (Sava)">Una</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kupa" title="Kupa">Kupa</a>, and especially from western <a href="/wiki/Slavonia" title="Slavonia">Slavonia</a>, migrated towards <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> and the present-day <a href="/wiki/Burgenland_Croats" title="Burgenland Croats">Burgenland Croats</a> are direct descendants of these settlers.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[43]</a></sup> To replace the fleeing population, the Habsburgs encouraged the people of Bosnia to provide military service in the <a href="/wiki/Military_Frontier" title="Military Frontier">Military Frontier</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament" title="Croatian Parliament">Croatian Parliament</a> supported <a href="/wiki/Emperor_Charles_VI" class="mw-redirect" title="Emperor Charles VI">King Charles III</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Pragmatic_Sanction_of_1713" title="Pragmatic Sanction of 1713">Pragmatic Sanction</a> and signed their own <a href="/wiki/Pragmatic_Sanction_in_1712" class="mw-redirect" title="Pragmatic Sanction in 1712">Pragmatic Sanction in 1712</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[44]</a></sup> Subsequently, the emperor pledged to respect all privileges and political rights of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg)" title="Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)">Kingdom of Croatia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Queen_Maria_Theresa" class="mw-redirect" title="Queen Maria Theresa">Queen Maria Theresa</a> made significant contributions to Croatian matters, such as introducing compulsory education. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg/220px-Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="133" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg/330px-Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg/440px-Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="621"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jellasics_harcosai_kozott.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Ban <a href="/wiki/Josip_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Josip Jelačić">Josip Jelačić</a> fought <a href="/wiki/Hungarians_in_1848_and_1849" class="mw-redirect" title="Hungarians in 1848 and 1849">Hungarians in 1848 and 1849</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Between 1797 and 1809, the <a href="/wiki/First_French_Empire" title="First French Empire">First French Empire</a> gradually occupied the entire eastern <a href="/wiki/Adriatic" class="mw-redirect" title="Adriatic">Adriatic</a> coastline and a substantial part of its hinterland, ending the Venetian and the Ragusan republics, establishing the <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_Provinces" title="Illyrian Provinces">Illyrian Provinces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_45-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-45">[40]</a></sup> In response, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_the_Adriatic_Sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Blockade of the Adriatic Sea">blockaded the Adriatic Sea</a>, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lissa_(1811)" title="Battle of Lissa (1811)">Battle of Vis</a> in 1811.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdkinsAdkins2008359–362_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdkinsAdkins2008359–362-50">[45]</a></sup> The Illyrian Provinces were captured by the Austrians in 1813 and absorbed by the <a href="/wiki/Austrian_Empire" title="Austrian Empire">Austrian Empire</a> following the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> in 1815. This led to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dalmatia" title="Kingdom of Dalmatia">Kingdom of Dalmatia</a> and the restoration of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Littoral" title="Croatian Littoral">Croatian Littoral</a> to the Kingdom of Croatia, now both under the same crown.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[46]</a></sup> The 1830s and 1840s saw <a href="/wiki/Romantic_nationalism" title="Romantic nationalism">romantic nationalism</a> inspire the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_National_Revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian National Revival">Croatian National Revival</a>, a political and cultural campaign advocating the unity of all <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">South Slavs</a> in the empire. Its primary focus was establishing a standard language as a counterweight to <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a> while promoting Croatian literature and culture.<sup id="cite_ref-CRIS-Stančić_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRIS-Stančić-52">[47]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Revolution_of_1848" title="Hungarian Revolution of 1848">Hungarian Revolution of 1848</a>, Croatia sided with the Austrians, Ban <a href="/wiki/Josip_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Josip Jelačić">Josip Jelačić</a> helping defeat the Hungarian forces in 1849 and ushering a <a href="/wiki/Germanization" class="mw-redirect" title="Germanization">Germanization</a> policy.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[48]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Austria-Hungary_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/290px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="224" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/435px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Austria-Hungary_map.svg/580px-Austria-Hungary_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="783" data-file-height="605"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Austria-Hungary_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia-Slavonia" title="Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia">Kingdom of Croatia-Slavonia</a> (no. 17) was an autonomous kingdom within <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> created in 1868 following the <a href="/wiki/Croatian-Hungarian_Settlement" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian-Hungarian Settlement">Croatian-Hungarian Settlement</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By the 1860s, failure of the policy became apparent, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Compromise_of_1867" title="Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867">Austro-Hungarian Compromise of 1867</a>. The creation of a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> between the Austrian Empire and the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Kingdom of Hungary</a> followed. The treaty left Croatia's status to Hungary, and it was resolved by the <a href="/wiki/Croatian%E2%80%93Hungarian_Settlement" title="Croatian–Hungarian Settlement">Croatian–Hungarian Settlement</a> of 1868 when kingdoms of Croatia and Slavonia were united.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[49]</a></sup> The Kingdom of Dalmatia remained under de facto Austrian control, while <a href="/wiki/Rijeka" title="Rijeka">Rijeka</a> retained the status of <a href="/wiki/Corpus_separatum_(Fiume)" title="Corpus separatum (Fiume)">Corpus separatum</a> introduced in 1779.<sup id="cite_ref-HR-HU-Heka_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HR-HU-Heka-42">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_rule_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Austro-Hungarian rule in Bosnia and Herzegovina">occupied Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> following the <a href="/wiki/1878_Treaty_of_Berlin" class="mw-redirect" title="1878 Treaty of Berlin">1878 Treaty of Berlin</a>, the Croatian Military Frontier was abolished. The territory returned to Croatia in 1881,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423_45-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005422–423-45">[40]</a></sup> under provisions of the Croatian-Hungarian settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Dubravica_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dubravica-56">[51]</a></sup> Renewed efforts to <a href="/wiki/Reform_Austria-Hungary" class="mw-redirect" title="Reform Austria-Hungary">reform Austria-Hungary</a>, entailing <a href="/wiki/Federalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Federalisation">federalisation</a> with Croatia as a federal unit, were stopped by the advent of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[52]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Yugoslav_Era_.281918.E2.80.931991.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Yugoslav_Era_(1918–1991)">Yugoslav Era (1918–1991)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Creation_of_Yugoslavia" title="Creation of Yugoslavia">Creation of Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banovina_of_Croatia" title="Banovina of Croatia">Banovina of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_in_Yugoslavia" title="World War II in Yugoslavia">World War II in Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia" title="Socialist Republic of Croatia">Socialist Republic of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>On 29 October 1918 the Croatian Parliament (<i>Sabor</i>) declared independence and decided to join the newly formed <a href="/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats,_and_Serbs" class="mw-redirect" title="State of Slovenes, Croats, and Serbs">State of Slovenes, Croats, and Serbs</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_43-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-43">[38]</a></sup> which in turn entered into union with the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a> on 4 December 1918 to form the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes">Kingdom of Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[53]</a></sup> The Croatian Parliament never ratified a decision to unite with Serbia and Montenegro.<sup id="cite_ref-Povijest-saborovanja_43-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Povijest-saborovanja-43">[38]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1921_constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="1921 constitution">1921 constitution</a> defining the country as a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> and abolition of Croatian Parliament and historical administrative divisions effectively ended Croatian autonomy. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/220px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/330px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg/440px-Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="312"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Radic_govori_na_skupstini.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Stjepan_Radi%C4%87" title="Stjepan Radić">Stjepan Radić</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Peasant_Party" title="Croatian Peasant Party">Croatian Peasant Party</a> who advocated federal organisation of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, at the assembly in Dubrovnik, 1928
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The new constitution was opposed by the most widely supported national political party—the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Peasant_Party" title="Croatian Peasant Party">Croatian Peasant Party</a> (HSS) led by <a href="/wiki/Stjepan_Radi%C4%87" title="Stjepan Radić">Stjepan Radić</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[54]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The political situation deteriorated further as Radić was assassinated in the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav Parliament">National Assembly</a> in 1928, leading to the dictatorship of King <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Yugoslavia" title="Alexander I of Yugoslavia">Alexander</a> in January 1929.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[55]</a></sup> The dictatorship formally ended in 1931 when the king imposed a more unitarian constitution and changed the name to Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[56]</a></sup> The HSS, now led by <a href="/wiki/Vladko_Ma%C4%8Dek" title="Vladko Maček">Vladko Maček</a>, continued to advocate federalisation of Yugoslavia, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Cvetkovi%C4%87%E2%80%93Ma%C4%8Dek_Agreement" title="Cvetković–Maček Agreement">Cvetković–Maček Agreement</a> of August 1939 and the autonomous <a href="/wiki/Banovina_of_Croatia" title="Banovina of Croatia">Banovina of Croatia</a>. The Yugoslav government retained control of the defence, internal security, foreign affairs, trade, and transport while other matters were left to the Croatian Sabor and a crown-appointed Ban.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004121–123_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004121–123-62">[57]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg/220px-Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="151" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg/330px-Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg/440px-Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg 2x" data-file-width="748" data-file-height="512"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87ev_trg_12.5.1945.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>People of <a href="/wiki/Zagreb_in_World_War_II" title="Zagreb in World War II">Zagreb celebrating liberation</a> from <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a> by <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a> on 12 May 1945
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In April 1941, <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia_was_occupied" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslavia was occupied">Yugoslavia was occupied</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Germany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a>. Following the invasion, parts of Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the region of <a href="/wiki/Syrmia" title="Syrmia">Syrmia</a> were incorporated into the <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a> (NDH), a Nazi-backed <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a>. Parts of Dalmatia were annexed by Italy and the northern Croatian regions of <a href="/wiki/Baranya_(region)" title="Baranya (region)">Baranja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Me%C4%91imurje" class="mw-redirect" title="Međimurje">Međimurje</a> by Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004153–156_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004153–156-63">[58]</a></sup> The NDH regime was led by <a href="/wiki/Ante_Paveli%C4%87" title="Ante Pavelić">Ante Pavelić</a> and ultranationalist <a href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">Ustaše</a>. NDH was trying to establish such an internal structure to be consistent with that of the <a href="/wiki/Third_Reich" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Reich">Third Reich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_(1922–1943)" title="Kingdom of Italy">Fascist Italy</a>, so its authorities introduced racial laws against <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Serbs_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbs in Croatia">Serbs</a>, many were imprisoned in <a href="/wiki/Concentration_camps_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Concentration camps in the Independent State of Croatia">concentration camps</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[59]</a></sup> The Ustaše regime murdered around 300,000 Serbs as part of the <a href="/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia">genocide campaign</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[60]</a></sup> Statistician <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_%C5%BDerjavi%C4%87" title="Vladimir Žerjavić">Vladimir Žerjavić</a> lists 217,000 as victims of terror by the Axis,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158-66">[61]</a></sup> including the genocide in the NDH.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004184_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004184-67">[62]</a></sup> The total number of Serb civilian and military deaths in the territory of the NDH was at around 330,000<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158-66">[61]</a></sup> to 370,000.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKočović2005XVII_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKočović2005XVII-68">[63]</a></sup> Of the almost 40,000 Jews in the NDH, only around 9,000 survived, while most of the 15,000 Roma were killed.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999136–137_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999136–137-69">[64]</a></sup> At the same time, anti-fascist Croats were targeted by the regime as well.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999138_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999138-70">[65]</a></sup> The Yugoslav Royalist and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_nationalist" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian nationalist">Serbian nationalist</a> <a href="/wiki/Chetniks" title="Chetniks">Chetniks</a>, a guerilla force that collaborated with the Axis, carried out <a href="/wiki/Chetnik_war_crimes_in_World_War_II" title="Chetnik war crimes in World War II">genocide against Croats and Bosniaks</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004184_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlemenčičŽagar2004184-67">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001747_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETomasevich2001747-71">[66]</a></sup> An estimated 47,000 to 68,000 Croats and Bosniaks died at the hands of the Chetniks, mostly civilians.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeiger201286,_103,_117_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeiger201286,_103,_117-72">[67]</a></sup> The total number of Croats who lost their lives during World War II from all causes, based on the studies of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_%C5%BDerjavi%C4%87" title="Vladimir Žerjavić">Vladimir Žerjavić</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bogoljub_Ko%C4%8Dovi%C4%87" title="Bogoljub Kočović">Bogoljub Kočović</a>, is estimated to be approximately 200,000.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[68]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg/220px-Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg/330px-Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg/440px-Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg 2x" data-file-width="576" data-file-height="431"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Event_in_Zagreb_in_honour_of_Tito.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Welcome of Tito in <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">Zagreb</a> 1945. In the picture from left: dignitaries of the Orthodox Church; a Partisan General; Auxiliary Bishop Josip Lach; Archbishop <a href="/wiki/Aloysius_Stepinac" title="Aloysius Stepinac">Aloysius Stepinac</a> and Croatian communist leader <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Bakari%C4%87" title="Vladimir Bakarić">Vladimir Bakarić</a> with other guests.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Movement_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="National Liberation Movement in Croatia">resistance movement</a> soon emerged. On 22 June 1941,<sup id="cite_ref-Pavličević_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pavličević-74">[69]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/1st_Sisak_Partisan_Detachment" class="mw-redirect" title="1st Sisak Partisan Detachment">1st Sisak Partisan Detachment</a> was formed near <a href="/wiki/Sisak" title="Sisak">Sisak</a>, the first military unit formed by a resistance movement in <a href="/wiki/German-occupied_Europe" title="German-occupied Europe">occupied Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pavlicevic-2007_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pavlicevic-2007-75">[70]</a></sup> That sparked the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisan" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav Partisan">Yugoslav Partisan</a> movement, a communist multi-ethnic anti-fascist resistance group led by <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[71]</a></sup> The movement grew fast, and at the <a href="/wiki/Tehran_Conference" title="Tehran Conference">Tehran Conference</a> in December 1943, the Partisans gained recognition from the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[72]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With Allied support in logistics, equipment, training and airpower, and with the assistance of <a href="/wiki/Soviet_troops" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet troops">Soviet troops</a> taking part in the 1944 <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Offensive" title="Belgrade Offensive">Belgrade Offensive</a>, the Partisans gained control of Yugoslavia and the border regions of <a href="/wiki/Trieste#World_War_II_and_its_aftermath" title="Trieste">Italy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carinthia_(state)#From_1920_to_the_Present" class="mw-redirect" title="Carinthia (state)">Austria</a> by May 1945, during which tens of thousands of members of the <a href="/wiki/NDH_armed_forces" class="mw-redirect" title="NDH armed forces">NDH armed forces</a>, as well as Croat refugees, were <a href="/wiki/Bleiburg_repatriations" title="Bleiburg repatriations">killed</a> by the Yugoslav Partisans.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[73]</a></sup> In the following years, <a href="/wiki/Germans_of_Croatia" title="Germans of Croatia">ethnic Germans</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Flight_and_expulsion_of_Germans_(1944%E2%80%9350)#Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="Flight and expulsion of Germans (1944–50)">persecution in Yugoslavia</a>, and many were interned in camps.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158_66-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGoldstein1999158-66">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The political aspirations of the Partisan movement were reflected in the <a href="/wiki/State_Anti-fascist_Council_for_the_National_Liberation_of_Croatia" title="State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia">State Anti-fascist Council for the National Liberation of Croatia</a>, which developed in 1943 as the bearer of Croatian statehood and later transformed into the Parliament of Croatia in 1945, and <a href="/wiki/AVNOJ" class="mw-redirect" title="AVNOJ">AVNOJ</a>—its counterpart at the Yugoslav level.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[75]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/220px-Nixontito19712.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="149" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/330px-Nixontito19712.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Nixontito19712.jpg/440px-Nixontito19712.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2934" data-file-height="1981"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nixontito19712.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> led <a href="/wiki/SFR_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="SFR Yugoslavia">SFR Yugoslavia</a> from 1944 to 1980; Pictured: Tito with the US president <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> in the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a>, 1971
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Croatia became a <a href="/wiki/Single-party" class="mw-redirect" title="Single-party">single-party</a> socialist <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia" title="Socialist Republic of Croatia">federal unit</a> of the <a href="/wiki/SFR_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="SFR Yugoslavia">SFR Yugoslavia</a>, ruled by the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Communists_of_Croatia" title="League of Communists of Croatia">Communists</a>, but having a degree of autonomy within the federation. In 1967, Croatian authors and linguists published a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_on_the_Status_and_Name_of_the_Croatian_Standard_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language">Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Standard Language</a> demanding equal treatment for the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Šute-Deklaracija_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Šute-Deklaracija-81">[76]</a></sup> The declaration contributed to a national movement seeking greater civil rights and redistribution of the Yugoslav economy, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Spring" title="Croatian Spring">Croatian Spring</a> of 1971, suppressed by Yugoslav leadership.<sup id="cite_ref-JL-Savka_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-Savka-82">[77]</a></sup> Still, the <a href="/wiki/1974_Yugoslav_Constitution" title="1974 Yugoslav Constitution">1974 Yugoslav Constitution</a> gave increased autonomy to federal units, basically fulfilling a goal of the Croatian Spring and providing a legal basis for independence of the federative constituents.<sup id="cite_ref-Rich_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rich-83">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the death of Yugoslav President Josip Broz Tito in 1980, the political situation in Yugoslavia deteriorated, with national tension fanned by the 1986 <a href="/wiki/SANU_Memorandum" title="SANU Memorandum">SANU Memorandum</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1989_coups_in_Vojvodina,_Kosovo_and_Montenegro" class="mw-redirect" title="1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo and Montenegro">1989 coups in Vojvodina, Kosovo, and Montenegro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005433_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005433-84">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[80]</a></sup> In January 1990, the Communist Party fragmented along national lines, with the Croatian <a href="/wiki/Political_faction" title="Political faction">faction</a> demanding a looser federation.<sup id="cite_ref-Pauković-14Congress-2009_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pauković-14Congress-2009-86">[81]</a></sup> In the same year, the <a href="/wiki/1990_Croatian_parliamentary_election" title="1990 Croatian parliamentary election">first multi-party elections</a> were held in Croatia, with <a href="/wiki/Franjo_Tu%C4%91man" title="Franjo Tuđman">Franjo Tuđman</a>'s win raising nationalist tensions further.<sup id="cite_ref-Independent-Tuđman-Obituary_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Independent-Tuđman-Obituary-87">[82]</a></sup> Some of the <a href="/wiki/Serbs_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbs in Croatia">Serbs in Croatia</a> left Sabor and declared the autonomy of what would soon become the unrecognised <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Serbian_Krajina" title="Republic of Serbian Krajina">Republic of Serbian Krajina</a>, intent on achieving independence from Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Autonomy-AUG1990_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Autonomy-AUG1990-88">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EE-CIS-book_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EE-CIS-book-89">[84]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Independent_Croatia_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Independent_Croatia_(1991–present)">Independent Croatia (1991–present)</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">Independence of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">Croatian War of Independence</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Croatia_since_1995" title="History of Croatia since 1995">History of Croatia since 1995</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/220px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/330px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG/440px-Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="380"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serb_T-55_Battle_of_the_Barracks.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Destroyed Yugoslav Army tank, a scene from the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">Croatian War of Independence</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As tensions rose, Croatia <a href="/wiki/Independence_of_Croatia" title="Independence of Croatia">declared independence</a> on 25 June 1991. However, the full implementation of the declaration only came into effect on 8 October 1991.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991_90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Declaration-26June1991-90">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991-91">[86]</a></sup> In the meantime, tensions escalated into <a href="/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence" title="Croatian War of Independence">overt war</a> when the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_People%27s_Army" title="Yugoslav People's Army">Yugoslav People's Army</a> (JNA) and various Serb paramilitary groups attacked Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Otkos10_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Otkos10-92">[87]</a></sup> By the end of 1991, a high-intensity conflict fought along a wide front reduced Croatia's control of only about two-thirds of its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Iceland_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Iceland-93">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LATimes-OccupiedPct-1Aug91_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LATimes-OccupiedPct-1Aug91-94">[89]</a></sup> The various Serb paramilitary groups then began pursuing a campaign of killing, terror, and expulsion of the Croats in the rebel territories, killing thousands<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[90]</a></sup> of Croat civilians and expelling or displacing as many as 400,000 Croats and other non-Serbs from their homes.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[91]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/220px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/330px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg/440px-Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="8218" data-file-height="5984"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tu%C4%91man_i_Ana_Havel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Franjo_Tu%C4%91man" title="Franjo Tuđman">Franjo Tuđman</a> was the first democratically elected <a href="/wiki/President_of_Croatia" title="President of Croatia">President of Croatia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 15 January 1992, Croatia gained <a href="/wiki/Diplomatic_recognition" title="Diplomatic recognition">diplomatic recognition</a> by the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">European Economic Community</a> members, and subsequently the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Germany-23Dec91_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Germany-23Dec91-97">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT-UN-membership_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-UN-membership-98">[93]</a></sup> The war effectively ended in August 1995 with a <a href="/wiki/Operation_Storm" title="Operation Storm">decisive victory</a> by Croatia;<sup id="cite_ref-LATimes-Storm-Complete_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LATimes-Storm-Complete-99">[94]</a></sup> the event is commemorated each year on 5 August as <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(Croatia)" title="Victory Day (Croatia)">Victory and Homeland Thanksgiving Day and the Day of Croatian Defenders</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[95]</a></sup> Following the Croatian victory, about 200,000 Serbs from the self-proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Serbian_Krajina" title="Republic of Serbian Krajina">Republic of Serbian Krajina</a> fled from the region.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-storm_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-storm-101">[96]</a></sup> Their lands were subsequently settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[97]</a></sup> The remaining occupied areas were restored to Croatia following the <a href="/wiki/Erdut_Agreement" title="Erdut Agreement">Erdut Agreement</a> of November 1995, with the process concluded in January 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-UNTAES-16Jan98-103">[98]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the end of the war, Croatia faced the challenges of post-war reconstruction, the return of refugees, advancing democratic principles, protection of human rights, and general social and economic development. The post-2000 period is characterised by democratisation, economic growth, structural and social reforms, as well as problems such as unemployment, corruption, and the inefficiency of the public administration.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia joined the <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> on 25 May 2000<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[100]</a></sup> and became a member of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> on 30 November 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[101]</a></sup> On 29 October 2001, Croatia signed a <a href="/wiki/Stabilization_and_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Stabilization and Association Agreement">Stabilization and Association Agreement</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[102]</a></sup> submitted a formal application for the EU membership in 2003,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[103]</a></sup> was given the status of candidate country in 2004,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[104]</a></sup> and began <a href="/wiki/2013_enlargement_of_the_European_Union#Negotiation_progress" title="2013 enlargement of the European Union">accession negotiations</a> in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup> In November 2000 and March 2001, the Parliament amended the Constitution, changing its bicameral structure back into historic unicameral and reducing the presidential powers.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[106]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="521" data-file-height="310"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Croatia became the 28th <a href="/wiki/EU" class="mw-redirect" title="EU">EU</a> member country on 1 July 2013
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
