      <p>Although the Croatian economy had enjoyed a significant boom in the early 2000s, the financial crisis in 2008 forced the government to cut public spending, thus provoking a public outcry.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup> On 1 April 2009, Croatia joined <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup> A wave of anti-government protests in early 2011 reflected a general dissatisfaction with the political and economic state.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[109]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia completed EU accession negotiations in 2011. A majority of Croatian voters opted in favour of country's EU membership at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Croatian_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2012 Croatian European Union membership referendum">2012 referendum</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[110]</a></sup> and Croatia joined the European Union effective 1 July 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[111]</a></sup> Croatia was affected by the <a href="/wiki/European_migrant_crisis" title="European migrant crisis">European migrant crisis</a> in 2015 when Hungary's closure of its borders with Serbia forced over 700,000 migrants to use Croatia as a transit country on their way to <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">Western Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[112]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 22 March 2020, a <a href="/wiki/2020_Zagreb_earthquake" title="2020 Zagreb earthquake">5.5 earthquake</a><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[113]</a></sup> struck Croatia, with the <a href="/wiki/Epicenter" title="Epicenter">epicenter</a> located 7 kilometres (4.3&nbsp;mi) north of <a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">Zagreb</a> city centre, inflicting heavy structural damage in the historic city centre and causing 27 injuries with one fatality. Over 1,900 buildings were reported to have become uninhabitable by the earthquake damage.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[114]</a></sup> The earthquake occurred during the <a href="/wiki/2020_coronavirus_pandemic_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="2020 coronavirus pandemic in Croatia">coronavirus pandemic</a> and caused problems in enforcement of the <a href="/wiki/Social_distancing" title="Social distancing">social distancing</a> measures set out by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Croatia" title="Government of Croatia">Government of Croatia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[116]</a></sup> It occurred during the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_the_Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Presidency of the Council of the European Union">Croatian Presidency</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_the_European_Union" title="Council of the European Union">Council of the European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[118]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Croatia" title="Geography of Croatia">Geography of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/320px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg" decoding="async" width="320" height="317" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/480px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg/640px-Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1912" data-file-height="1894"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Satellite_image_of_Croatia_in_September_2003.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Satellite image of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia is in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and Southeast Europe, on the coast of the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>. It borders Hungary to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Serbia" title="Serbia">Serbia</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> to the southeast and <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a> to the northwest. It lies mostly between latitudes <a href="/wiki/42nd_parallel_north" title="42nd parallel north">42°</a> and <a href="/wiki/47%C2%B0_N" class="mw-redirect" title="47° N">47° N</a> and longitudes <a href="/wiki/13th_meridian_east" title="13th meridian east">13°</a> and <a href="/wiki/20%C2%B0_E" class="mw-redirect" title="20° E">20° E</a>. Part of the territory in the extreme south surrounding <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">Dubrovnik</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Practical_exclave" class="mw-redirect" title="Practical exclave">practical exclave</a> connected to the rest of the mainland by <a href="/wiki/Territorial_waters" title="Territorial waters">territorial waters</a>, but separated on land by a short coastline strip belonging to Bosnia and Herzegovina around <a href="/wiki/Neum" title="Neum">Neum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pelje%C5%A1ac_Bridge" title="Pelješac Bridge">Pelješac Bridge</a>, scheduled to open in 2022, will connect the exclave with the mainland Croatia. </p>
      <p>The territory covers 56,594 square kilometres (21,851 square miles), consisting of 56,414 square kilometres (21,782 square miles) of land and 128 square kilometres (49 square miles) of water. It is the 127th largest country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> Elevation ranges from the mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">Dinaric Alps</a> with the highest point of the <a href="/wiki/Dinara" title="Dinara">Dinara</a> peak at 1,831 metres (6,007 feet) near the border with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the south<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> to the shore of the Adriatic Sea which makes up its entire southwest border. Insular Croatia consists of over <a href="/wiki/A_thousand_islands_and_islets" class="mw-redirect" title="A thousand islands and islets">a thousand islands and islets</a> varying in size, 48 of which <a href="/wiki/List_of_inhabited_islands_of_Croatia" title="List of inhabited islands of Croatia">permanently inhabited</a>. The largest islands are <a href="/wiki/Cres" title="Cres">Cres</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krk" title="Krk">Krk</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> each of them having an area of around 405 square kilometres (156 square miles). </p>
      <p>The hilly northern parts of <a href="/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje" title="Hrvatsko Zagorje">Hrvatsko Zagorje</a> and the flat plains of Slavonia in the east which is part of the <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Basin" title="Pannonian Basin">Pannonian Basin</a> are traversed by major rivers such as <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drava" title="Drava">Drava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kupa" title="Kupa">Kupa</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a>. The Danube, Europe's second longest river, runs through the city of <a href="/wiki/Vukovar" title="Vukovar">Vukovar</a> in the extreme east and forms part of the border with <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>. The central and southern regions near the Adriatic coastline and islands consist of low mountains and forested highlands. Natural resources found in the country in quantities significant enough for production include oil, coal, bauxite, low-grade iron ore, calcium, gypsum, natural asphalt, silica, mica, clays, salt, and hydropower.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Karst_topography" class="mw-redirect" title="Karst topography">Karst topography</a> makes up about half of Croatia and is especially prominent in the Dinaric Alps.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[121]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/A_number_of_deep_caves_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="A number of deep caves in Croatia">several deep caves in Croatia</a>, 49 of which deeper than 250&nbsp;m (820.21&nbsp;ft), 14 of them deeper than 500&nbsp;m (1,640.42&nbsp;ft) and three deeper than 1,000&nbsp;m (3,280.84&nbsp;ft). Croatia's most famous lakes are the <a href="/wiki/Plitvice_lakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Plitvice lakes">Plitvice lakes</a>, a system of 16 lakes with waterfalls connecting them over <a href="/wiki/Dolomite_(mineral)" title="Dolomite (mineral)">dolomite</a> and <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a> cascades. The lakes are renowned for their distinctive colours, ranging from turquoise to mint green, grey or blue.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC-Plitvice_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Plitvice-127">[122]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/220px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/330px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg/440px-Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="547"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Winter_bora_in_Senj.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bora_(wind)" title="Bora (wind)">Bora</a> is a dry, cold wind which blows from the mainland out to sea, whose gusts can reach hurricane strength, particularly in the channel below <a href="/wiki/Velebit" title="Velebit">Velebit</a>, e.g. in the town of <a href="/wiki/Senj" title="Senj">Senj</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Most of Croatia has a moderately warm and rainy <a href="/wiki/Continental_climate" title="Continental climate">continental climate</a> as defined by the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>. Mean monthly temperature ranges between −3&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a> (27&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a>) in January and 18&nbsp;°C (64&nbsp;°F) in July. The coldest parts of the country are <a href="/wiki/Lika" title="Lika">Lika</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gorski_Kotar" title="Gorski Kotar">Gorski Kotar</a> where the snowy forested climate is found at elevations above 1,200 metres (3,900 feet). The warmest areas of Croatia are at the Adriatic coast and especially in its immediate hinterland characterised by the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_climate" title="Mediterranean climate">Mediterranean climate</a>, as the temperature highs are moderated by the sea. Consequently, temperature peaks are more pronounced in the continental areas. The lowest temperature of −35.5&nbsp;°C (−31.9&nbsp;°F) was recorded on 3 February 1919 in <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Cakovec" title="Čakovec">Čakovec</a>, and the highest temperature of 42.8&nbsp;°C (109.0&nbsp;°F) was recorded on 4 August 1981 in <a href="/wiki/Plo%C4%8De" title="Ploče">Ploče</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542-128">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-record_temp_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-record_temp-129">[124]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mean annual precipitation ranges between 600 millimetres (24 inches) and 3,500 millimetres (140 inches) depending on geographic region and prevailing climate type. The least precipitation is recorded in the outer islands (<a href="/wiki/Bi%C5%A1evo" title="Biševo">Biševo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lastovo" title="Lastovo">Lastovo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Svetac" title="Svetac">Svetac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vis_(island)" title="Vis (island)">Vis</a>) and the eastern parts of Slavonia. However, in the latter case, it occurs mostly during the <a href="/wiki/Growing_season" title="Growing season">growing season</a>. The maximum precipitation levels are observed on the Dinara mountain range and in Gorski Kotar.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201542-128">[123]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Prevailing winds in the interior are light to moderate northeast or southwest, and in the coastal area, prevailing winds are determined by local area features. Higher wind velocities are more often recorded in cooler months along the coast, generally as the cool northeasterly <a href="/wiki/Bora_(wind)" title="Bora (wind)">bura</a> or less frequently as the warm southerly <a href="/wiki/Jugo" class="mw-redirect" title="Jugo">jugo</a>. The sunniest parts of the country are the outer islands, Hvar and Korčula, where more than 2700 hours of sunshine are recorded per year, followed by the middle and southern Adriatic Sea area in general, and northern Adriatic coast, all with more than 2000 hours of sunshine per year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201543_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia_201543-130">[125]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Protected areas of Croatia">Protected areas of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Register_of_Protected_Natural_Values_of_Croatia" title="Register of Protected Natural Values of Croatia">Register of Protected Natural Values of Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_and_Cultural_Heritage_of_Croatia" title="Natural and Cultural Heritage of Croatia">Natural and Cultural Heritage of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG/220px-Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG/330px-Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG/440px-Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG 2x" data-file-width="5472" data-file-height="3648"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kopa%C4%8Dki_rit_wooden_trail.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Wooden trail through <a href="/wiki/Nature_park" title="Nature park">nature park</a> <a href="/wiki/Kopa%C4%8Dki_Rit" title="Kopački Rit">Kopački Rit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Osijek-Baranja_County" title="Osijek-Baranja County">Osijek-Baranja County</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia can be subdivided between several <a href="/wiki/Ecoregion" title="Ecoregion">ecoregions</a> because of its climate and geomorphology. The country is consequently one of the richest in Europe in terms of biodiversity.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[126]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[127]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[128]</a></sup> There are four types of biogeographical regions in Croatia—the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Biogeographic_Region" title="Mediterranean Biogeographic Region">Mediterranean</a> along the coast and in its immediate hinterland, <a href="/wiki/Alpine_Biogeographic_Region" title="Alpine Biogeographic Region">Alpine</a> in most of Lika and Gorski Kotar, <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Biogeographic_Region" title="Pannonian Biogeographic Region">Pannonian</a> along Drava and Danube, and <a href="/wiki/Continental_Biogeographic_Region" title="Continental Biogeographic Region">Continental</a> in the remaining areas. The most significant are <a href="/wiki/Karst" title="Karst">karst</a> habitats which include submerged karst, such as <a href="/wiki/Zrmanja" title="Zrmanja">Zrmanja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Krka_(Croatia)" title="Krka (Croatia)">Krka</a> canyons and tufa barriers, as well as underground habitats. The country contains three ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Dinaric Mountains mixed forests">Dinaric Mountains mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_mixed_forests" title="Pannonian mixed forests">Pannonian mixed forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_deciduous_forests" title="Illyrian deciduous forests">Illyrian deciduous forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-134">[129]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The karst geology harbours approximately <a href="/wiki/7,000_caves_and_pits" class="mw-redirect" title="7,000 caves and pits">7,000 caves and pits</a>, some of which are the habitat of the only known aquatic cave <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrate</a>—the <a href="/wiki/Olm" title="Olm">olm</a>. Forests are also significantly present in the country, as they cover 2,490,000 hectares (6,200,000 acres) representing 44% of Croatian land surface. Other habitat types include wetlands, grasslands, bogs, fens, scrub habitats, coastal and marine habitats.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> In terms of <a href="/wiki/Phytogeography" title="Phytogeography">phytogeography</a>, Croatia is a part of the <a href="/wiki/Boreal_Kingdom" title="Boreal Kingdom">Boreal Kingdom</a> and is a part of Illyrian and Central European provinces of the <a href="/wiki/Circumboreal_Region" title="Circumboreal Region">Circumboreal Region</a> and the Adriatic province of the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean Region">Mediterranean Region</a>. The <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">World Wide Fund for Nature</a> divides Croatia between three ecoregions—Pannonian mixed forests, <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Dinaric Mountains mixed forests">Dinaric Mountains mixed forests</a> and <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_deciduous_forests" title="Illyrian deciduous forests">Illyrian deciduous forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DU-Sustdev_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DU-Sustdev-136">[131]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Telascica-Cliff.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/220px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/330px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Telascica-Cliff.JPG/440px-Telascica-Cliff.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Telascica-Cliff.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Tela%C5%A1%C4%87ica_Nature_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Telašćica Nature Park">Telašćica Nature Park</a> is one of <a href="/wiki/444_protected_areas_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="444 protected areas of Croatia">444 protected areas of Croatia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>There are 37,000 known species in Croatia, but their actual number is estimated to be between 50,000 and 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> The claim is supported by nearly 400 new taxa of <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a> discovered in Croatia in the first half of the 2000s alone.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> There are more than a thousand endemic species, especially in Velebit and Biokovo mountains, Adriatic islands and karst rivers. Legislation protects 1,131 species.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> The most serious threat to species is the loss and degradation of habitats. A further problem is presented by invasive alien species, especially <i><a href="/wiki/Caulerpa_taxifolia" title="Caulerpa taxifolia">Caulerpa taxifolia</a></i> algae. Croatia had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 4.92/10, ranking it 113th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-137">[132]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The invasive algae are regularly monitored and removed to protect the <a href="/wiki/Benthic_habitat" class="mw-redirect" title="Benthic habitat">benthic habitat</a>. Indigenous sorts of cultivated plants and breeds of domesticated animals are also numerous. Those include five breeds of horses, five breeds of cattle, eight breeds of sheep, two breeds of pigs, and a poultry breed. The indigenous breeds include nine endangered or critically endangered ones.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> There are 444 <a href="/wiki/Protected_areas_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Protected areas of Croatia">protected areas of Croatia</a>, encompassing 9% of the country. Those include eight <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of national parks of Croatia">national parks</a>, two strict reserves, and ten <a href="/wiki/Nature_park" title="Nature park">nature parks</a>. The most famous protected area and the oldest <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national park</a> in Croatia is the <a href="/wiki/Plitvice_Lakes_National_Park" title="Plitvice Lakes National Park">Plitvice Lakes National Park</a>, a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites in Croatia">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>. Velebit Nature Park is a part of the UNESCO <a href="/wiki/Man_and_the_Biosphere_Programme" title="Man and the Biosphere Programme">Man and the Biosphere Programme</a>. The strict and special reserves, as well as the national and nature parks, are managed and protected by the central government, while other protected areas are managed by counties. In 2005, the National Ecological Network was set up, as the first step in the preparation of the EU accession and joining of the <a href="/wiki/Natura_2000" title="Natura 2000">Natura 2000</a> network.<sup id="cite_ref-MCult-Biodiversity_135-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MCult-Biodiversity-135">[130]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Croatia" title="Politics of Croatia">Politics of Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Croatia" title="Human rights in Croatia">Human rights in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:858px">
       <div class="thumbinner">
        <div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto">
         <a href="/wiki/File:St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg" class="image" title="St. Mark's Square in Zagreb – Left-to-right: Banski dvori official residence of the Croatian Government, St. Mark's Church and Croatian Parliament"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg/850px-St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg" decoding="async" width="850" height="239" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1180" data-file-height="332"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:St._Marks_Sq_Zagreb_pano.jpg" title="File:St. Marks Sq Zagreb pano.jpg"> </a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square_in_Zagreb" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Mark's Square in Zagreb">St. Mark's Square in Zagreb</a> – <i>Left-to-right</i>: <a href="/wiki/Banski_dvori" title="Banski dvori">Banski dvori</a> official residence of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Government">Croatian Government</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Church,_Zagreb" title="St. Mark's Church, Zagreb">St. Mark's Church</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament" title="Croatian Parliament">Croatian Parliament</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Republic of Croatia is a unitary state using a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a> of governance. With the collapse of the ruling communist party in SFR Yugoslavia, Croatia organised its first <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_elections" class="mw-redirect" title="Multi-party elections">multi-party elections</a> and adopted its <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Croatia" title="Constitution of Croatia">present Constitution</a> in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Elections2-HRV1990_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Elections2-HRV1990-138">[133]</a></sup> It <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_independence" title="Declaration of independence">declared independence</a> on 8 October 1991 which led to the <a href="/wiki/Break-up_of_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="Break-up of Yugoslavia">break-up of Yugoslavia</a> and countries international recognition by the United Nations in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991_91-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-Independence-8Oct1991-91">[86]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT-UN-membership_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-UN-membership-98">[93]</a></sup> Under its 1990 Constitution, Croatia operated a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_system" title="Semi-presidential system">semi-presidential system</a> until 2000 when it switched to a parliamentary system.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC-CroProfile_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-CroProfile-139">[134]</a></sup> Government powers in Croatia are legislative, executive, and judiciary powers.<sup id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-140">[135]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_(6558633915).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg/220px-Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg/330px-Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg/440px-Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_%286558633915%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2496" data-file-height="1664"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Predstavljanje_nove_Vlade_RH_(6558633915).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Grand Hall of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Parliament_%E2%88%92_Sabor" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Parliament − Sabor">Croatian Parliament − Sabor</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Croatia" title="President of Croatia">President of the Republic</a> (<a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">Predsjednik Republike</i>) is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, directly elected to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to two terms. In addition to being the <a href="/wiki/Commander_in_chief" class="mw-redirect" title="Commander in chief">commander in chief</a> of the armed forces, the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the parliament and has some influence on foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-140">[135]</a></sup> The most recent presidential elections were held on 5 January 2020, when <a href="/wiki/Zoran_Milanovi%C4%87" title="Zoran Milanović">Zoran Milanović</a> became the new president. He took the <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_office" title="Oath of office">oath of office</a> on 18 February 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[136]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Government" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Government">Government</a> is headed by the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Croatia" title="Prime Minister of Croatia">Prime Minister</a>, who has four deputy prime ministers and 16 ministers in charge of particular sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-Govt-Ministers_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Govt-Ministers-142">[137]</a></sup> As the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executive branch</a>, it is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget, executing the laws, and guiding the foreign and internal policies. The Government is seated at <a href="/wiki/Banski_dvori" title="Banski dvori">Banski dvori</a> in Zagreb.<sup id="cite_ref-VRH-PoliticalStructure_140-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VRH-PoliticalStructure-140">[135]</a></sup> Since 19 October 2016, Croatian Prime Minister has been <a href="/wiki/Andrej_Plenkovi%C4%87" title="Andrej Plenković">Andrej Plenković</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[138]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament (<i><i lang="hr" title="Croatian-language text">Sabor</i></i>) holds <a href="/wiki/Legislative_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative power">legislative power</a>. A second <a href="/wiki/Chambers_of_parliament" class="mw-redirect" title="Chambers of parliament">chamber</a>, the <i>House of Counties</i>, set up in 1993 according to the 1990 Constitution, was abolished in 2001. The number of Sabor members can vary from 100 to 160. They are all elected by popular vote to serve four-year terms. The sessions of the Sabor take place from 15 January to 15 July, and from 15 September to 15 December.<sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-about_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-about-144">[139]</a></sup> The two largest <a href="/wiki/Political_parties_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Political parties in Croatia">political parties in Croatia</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Democratic_Union" title="Croatian Democratic Union">Croatian Democratic Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Social_Democratic_Party_of_Croatia" title="Social Democratic Party of Croatia">Social Democratic Party of Croatia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-MPs_145-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-MPs-145">[140]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_judicial_system">Law and judicial system</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Croatia" title="Law of Croatia">Law of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/220px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/330px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg/440px-Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ustavni_sud_RH_nakon_obnove.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Seat of the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia" title="Constitutional Court of Croatia">Constitutional Court</a> on the <a href="/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb" title="St. Mark's Square, Zagreb">St. Mark's Square, Zagreb</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has a <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system in which law arises primarily from written statutes, with judges serving merely as implementers and not creators of law. Its development was largely influenced by German and Austrian legal systems. Croatian law is divided into two principal areas—<a href="/wiki/Private_law" title="Private law">private</a> and <a href="/wiki/Public_law" title="Public law">public law</a>. By the time <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Croatia_to_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Accession of Croatia to the European Union">EU accession negotiations</a> were completed on 30 June 2010, Croatian legislation was fully harmonised with the <a href="/wiki/Community_acquis" class="mw-redirect" title="Community acquis">Community acquis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DELHRV-overview_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DELHRV-overview-146">[141]</a></sup> The main law in the county is the Constitution adopted on 22 December 1990. </p>
      <p>The main national courts are the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia" title="Constitutional Court of Croatia">Constitutional Court</a>, which oversees violations of the Constitution, and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Croatia" title="Supreme Court of Croatia">Supreme Court</a>, which is the highest court of appeal. There are also Administrative, Commercial, <a href="/wiki/County_Court" class="mw-redirect" title="County Court">County</a>, Misdemeanor, and Municipal courts.<sup id="cite_ref-VSRH-about_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VSRH-about-147">[142]</a></sup> Cases falling within judicial jurisdiction are in the first instance decided by a single professional judge, while appeals are deliberated in mixed tribunals of professional judges. Lay magistrates also participate in trials.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[143]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/State%27s_Attorney_Office_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia" title="State's Attorney Office of the Republic of Croatia">State's Attorney Office</a> is the judicial body constituted of public prosecutors empowered to instigate prosecution of perpetrators of offences.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[144]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Law enforcement agencies are organised under the authority of the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Interior_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of the Interior (Croatia)">Ministry of the Interior</a> which consist primarily of the national police force. Croatia's security service is the <a href="/wiki/Security_and_Intelligence_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Security and Intelligence Agency">Security and Intelligence Agency</a> (SOA).<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">Counties of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/NUTS_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="NUTS of Croatia">NUTS of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg/330px-Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg/440px-Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3072" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vara%C5%BEdin_-_panoramio.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin" title="Varaždin">Varaždin</a>, capital of Croatia between 1767 and 1776, is the seat of <a href="/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin_county" class="mw-redirect" title="Varaždin county">Varaždin county</a>; Pictured: Old Town fortress, one of 15 Croatia's sites inscribed on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Croatia#Tentative_list" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Croatia">UNESCO World Heritage tentative list</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia was first subdivided into counties in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Medieval-Counties_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Medieval-Counties-152">[147]</a></sup> The divisions changed over time to reflect losses of territory to Ottoman conquest and subsequent liberation of the same territory, changes of the political status of Dalmatia, Dubrovnik, and <a href="/wiki/Istria" title="Istria">Istria</a>. The traditional division of the country into counties was abolished in the 1920s when the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes and the subsequent Kingdom of Yugoslavia introduced <a href="/wiki/Oblast" title="Oblast">oblasts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Subdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia">banovinas</a> respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005429_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrucht2005429-153">[148]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Communist-ruled Croatia, as a constituent part of post-World War II Yugoslavia, abolished earlier divisions and introduced municipalities, subdividing Croatia into approximately one hundred municipalities. Counties were reintroduced in 1992 legislation, significantly altered in terms of territory relative to the pre-1920s subdivisions. In 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Transleithania" class="mw-redirect" title="Transleithania">Transleithanian</a> part of Croatia was divided into eight counties with their seats in <a href="/wiki/Bjelovar" title="Bjelovar">Bjelovar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gospi%C4%87" title="Gospić">Gospić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ogulin" title="Ogulin">Ogulin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Osijek" title="Osijek">Osijek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Po%C5%BEega,_Croatia" title="Požega, Croatia">Požega</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin" title="Varaždin">Varaždin</a>, Vukovar, and Zagreb, and the 1992 legislation established 14 counties in the same territory.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBiondich200011_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBiondich200011-154">[149]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CountiesAct1992_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CountiesAct1992-155">[150]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the counties were re-established in 1992, Croatia is divided into 20 <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">counties</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Capital_city_of_Zagreb" class="mw-redirect" title="Capital city of Zagreb">capital city of Zagreb</a>, the latter having the authority and legal status of a county and a city at the same time. Borders of the counties changed in some instances since, with the latest revision taking place in 2006. The counties subdivide into 127 <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of cities in Croatia">cities</a> and 429 <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Croatia" title="Municipalities of Croatia">municipalities</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CountiesAct2006_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CountiesAct2006-156">[151]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nomenclature_of_Territorial_Units_for_Statistics" title="Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics">Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics</a> (NUTS) <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Division of Croatia">division of Croatia</a> is performed in several tiers. NUTS 1 level places the entire country in a single unit, while there are three NUTS 2 regions. Those are Northwest Croatia, Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia, and Adriatic Croatia. The latter encompasses all the counties along the Adriatic coast. Northwest Croatia includes Koprivnica-Križevci, Krapina-Zagorje, Međimurje, Varaždin, the city of Zagreb, and Zagreb counties and the Central and Eastern (Pannonian) Croatia includes the remaining areas—Bjelovar-Bilogora, Brod-Posavina, Karlovac, Osijek-Baranja, Požega-Slavonia, Sisak-Moslavina, Virovitica-Podravina, and Vukovar-Syrmia counties. Individual counties and the city of Zagreb also represent NUTS 3 level subdivision units in Croatia. The NUTS <a href="/wiki/Administrative_division" title="Administrative division">Local administrative unit</a> divisions are two-tiered. LAU 1 divisions match the counties and the city of Zagreb in effect making those the same as NUTS 3 units, while LAU 2 subdivisions correspond to the cities and municipalities of Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[152]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="position: relative; ;">

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Croatia" title="Foreign relations of Croatia">Foreign relations of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has established diplomatic relations with 194 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[153]</a></sup> As of 2020, Croatia maintains a <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Croatia" title="List of diplomatic missions of Croatia">network</a> of 57 embassies, 30 consulates and eight permanent diplomatic missions abroad. Furthermore, there are 56 foreign embassies and 67 <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">consulates</a> in the Republic of Croatia in addition to offices of international organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/European_Bank_for_Reconstruction_and_Development" title="European Bank for Reconstruction and Development">European Bank for Reconstruction and Development</a> (EBRD), <a href="/wiki/International_Organization_for_Migration" title="International Organization for Migration">International Organization for Migration</a> (IOM), <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO), <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Tribunal_for_the_former_Yugoslavia" title="International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia">International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia</a> (ICTY), <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">United Nations Development Programme</a> (UNDP), <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_High_Commissioner_for_Refugees" title="United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees">United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees</a> (UNHCR), and <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[154]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png/220px-Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="96" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png/330px-Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png/440px-Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Visa_requirements_for_Croatian_citizens.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Visa-free entry countries for Croatian citizens in green, <a href="/wiki/EU" class="mw-redirect" title="EU">EU</a> in blue (see <a href="/wiki/Citizenship_of_the_European_Union" title="Citizenship of the European Union">citizenship of the European Union</a>)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/220px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="79" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/330px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg/440px-Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1191" data-file-height="428"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Podizanje_NATO_zastave_070409_pano_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Flag hoisting ceremony at <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Croatia)">Ministry of Defence</a> marking Croatian accession to <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 2009
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2019, the Croatian <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_and_European_Integration_(Croatia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration (Croatia)">Ministry of Foreign Affairs and European Integration</a> employed 1,381<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The date of the event predicted near this tag has passed. (January 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> personnel and expended 765.295&nbsp;million kunas (€101.17&nbsp;million).<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[155]</a></sup> Stated aims of Croatian foreign policy include enhancing relations with neighbouring countries, developing international co-operation and promotion of the Croatian economy and Croatia itself.<sup id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Goals_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Goals-161">[156]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2003, Croatian foreign policy has focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming a <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a> (EU).<sup id="cite_ref-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL-162">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic-163">[158]</a></sup> In December 2011, Croatia completed the EU accession negotiations and signed <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Accession_2011" title="Treaty of Accession 2011">an EU accession treaty</a> on 9 December 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-EU-Negotiations-Completed_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-Negotiations-Completed-164">[159]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EU-Accession-Treaty_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-Accession-Treaty-165">[160]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Croatia_joined_the_European_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatia joined the European Union">Croatia joined the European Union</a> on 1 July 2013 marking the end of a process started in 2001 by signing of the <a href="/wiki/Stabilisation_and_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Stabilisation and Association Agreement">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a> and Croatian application for the EU membership in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Croatia-EU-2013_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Croatia-EU-2013-166">[161]</a></sup> A recurring obstacle to the negotiations was Croatia's ICTY co-operation record and Slovenian blocking of the negotiations because of <a href="/wiki/Croatia%E2%80%93Slovenia_border_disputes" title="Croatia–Slovenia border disputes">Croatia–Slovenia border disputes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[162]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[163]</a></sup> The latter should be resolved through an Arbitration Agreement of 4 November 2009, approved by national parliaments and a referendum in Slovenia.,<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Croatia-Slovenia-Arbitration_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Croatia-Slovenia-Arbitration-169">[164]</a></sup> but due to the events during arbitration, Croatia does not accept results. As of 2021, Croatia has unsolved border issues with all neighbouring former Yugoslav countries (Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Serbia, Slovenia).<sup id="cite_ref-Border_issues_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Border_issues-170">[165]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Another strategic Croatian foreign policy goal for the 2000s was <a href="/wiki/Croatia%E2%80%93NATO_relations" title="Croatia–NATO relations">NATO membership</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-NATO-StrategicGoals-NCL-162">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic_163-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sabor-EU-NATO-Strategic-163">[158]</a></sup> Croatia was included in the <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> in 2000, invited to <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> membership in 2008 and formally joined the alliance on 1 April 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-Bush-Zagreb_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-Bush-Zagreb-171">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBC-Croatia-NATO_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-Croatia-NATO-172">[167]</a></sup> Croatia became a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> for the 2008–2009 term, assuming the presidency in December 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-MVPEI-UNSC-2008-2009_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-UNSC-2008-2009-173">[168]</a></sup> The country is preparing to join the <a href="/wiki/Schengen_Area" title="Schengen Area">Schengen Area</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[169]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Croatia_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of Croatia Armed Forces">Republic of Croatia Armed Forces</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/220px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/330px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg/440px-US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="1369"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_021029-N-1955P-020_Navy_aircraft_participate_in_Joint_Wings_2002.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Croatian_Air_Force" title="Croatian Air Force">Croatian Air Force</a> and <a href="/wiki/US_Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="US Navy">US Navy</a> aircraft participate in multinational training, 2002
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Croatian Armed Forces (CAF) consist of the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Air_Force_and_Air_Defence" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Air Force and Air Defence">Air Force</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Army" title="Croatian Army">Army</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Navy" title="Croatian Navy">Navy</a> branches in addition to the Education and Training Command and Support Command. The CAF is headed by the <a href="/wiki/General_Staff_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia" title="General Staff of the Armed Forces of the Republic of Croatia">General Staff</a>, which reports to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Croatia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Croatia)">Defence Minister</a>, who in turn reports to the President. According to the constitution, the President is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the armed forces. In case of immediate threat during wartime, he issues orders directly to the General Staff.<sup id="cite_ref-CAFstructure_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAFstructure-175">[170]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the 1991–95 war, defence spending and CAF size have been in constant decline. As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, military spending was an estimated 1.68% of the country's GDP, which placed Croatia 67th.<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[171]</a></sup> Since 2005 the budget was kept below 2% of GDP, down from the record high of 11.1% in 1994.<sup id="cite_ref-sipri_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sipri-177">[172]</a></sup> Traditionally relying on many conscripts, CAF also went through a period of reforms focused on downsizing, restructuring and <a href="/wiki/Professionalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Professionalisation">professionalisation</a> in the years before <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Croatia_to_NATO" class="mw-redirect" title="Accession of Croatia to NATO">accession to NATO</a> in April 2009. According to a presidential decree issued in 2006, the CAF employs around 18,100 active duty military personnel, 3,000 civilians and 2,000 voluntary conscripts between 18 and 30 years old in peacetime.<sup id="cite_ref-CAFstructure_175-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CAFstructure-175">[170]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg/220px-Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg/330px-Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg/440px-Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Partner_in_battle_150914-A-CR001-007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A Croatian Army Soldier works with a U.S. Army Soldier from the 173rd Airborne Brigade in a situational training lane during Immediate Response 15 in <a href="/wiki/Slunj" title="Slunj">Slunj</a>, Croatia.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Compulsory conscription was abolished in January 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> Until 2008 military service was obligatory for men at age 18 and conscripts served six-month tours of duty, reduced in 2001 from the earlier scheme of nine-month conscription tours. Conscientious objectors could instead opt for an eight-month civilian service.<sup id="cite_ref-vojnirokkraci_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vojnirokkraci-178">[173]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of May&nbsp;2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the Croatian military had 72 members stationed in foreign countries as part of United Nations-led international peacekeeping forces.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[174]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 323 troops serve the NATO-led <a href="/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force" title="International Security Assistance Force">ISAF</a> force in Afghanistan. Another 156 with the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Force" title="Kosovo Force">KFOR</a> in Kosovo.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia also has a <a href="/wiki/Military_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Military industry">military industry</a> sector which exported around 493&nbsp;million kunas (€65,176&nbsp;million) worth of military equipment and armament in 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[177]</a></sup> Croatian-made weapons and vehicles used by CAF include the standard sidearm <a href="/wiki/HS2000" title="HS2000">HS2000</a> manufactured by <a href="/wiki/HS_Produkt" title="HS Produkt">HS Produkt</a> and the <a href="/wiki/M-84D" title="M-84D">M-84D</a> battle tank designed by the <a href="/wiki/%C4%90uro_%C4%90akovi%C4%87_factory" class="mw-redirect" title="Đuro Đaković factory">Đuro Đaković factory</a>. Uniforms and helmets worn by CAF soldiers are also locally produced and successfully marketed to other countries.<sup id="cite_ref-vojna_ind_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vojna_ind-183">[178]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Croatia" title="Economy of Croatia">Economy of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">

          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div style="float:left; margin-right:10px">

         </tr>

         </tr>

          <td>4</td>
