         </tr>
        </tbody>
       </table> 
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has a <a href="/wiki/High-income" class="mw-redirect" title="High-income">high-income</a> economy.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Bank_Country_Classification_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank_Country_Classification-186">[181]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> data projects that Croatian <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> stands at $60,688&nbsp;billion, or $14,816 per capita for 2018 while <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> GDP stands at $107.406&nbsp;billion, or $26,221 per capita.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[182]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a>, Croatian GDP per capita in PPS stood at 65% of the EU average in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Real GDP growth in 2018 was 2,6 per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-Eurostat-GDPGrowth_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Eurostat-GDPGrowth-189">[184]</a></sup> The average net salary of a Croatian worker in October 2019 was 6,496 <a href="/wiki/Croatian_kuna" title="Croatian kuna">HRK</a> per month (roughly 873 EUR), and the average gross salary was 8,813 HRK per month (roughly 1,185 EUR).<sup id="cite_ref-salary7161_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-salary7161-190">[185]</a></sup> As of July&nbsp;2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the unemployment rate dropped to 7.2% from 9.6% in December 2018. The number of unemployed persons was 106.703. Unemployment Rate in Croatia between 1996 and 2018 averaged 17.38%, reaching an all-time high of 23.60% in January 2002 and a record low of 8.40% in September 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[186]</a></sup> In 2017, economic output was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Service_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Service sector">service sector</a> accounting for 70.1% of GDP, followed by the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_sector" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial sector">industrial sector</a> with 26.2% and agriculture accounting for 3.7% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-192">[187]</a></sup> According to 2017 data, 1.9% of the workforce were employed in agriculture, 27.3% by industry and 70.8% in services.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-192">[187]</a></sup> Shipbuilding, food processing, pharmaceuticals, information technology, biochemical, and timber industry dominate the industrial sector. In 2018, Croatian exports were valued at 108 billion kunas (€14.61&nbsp;billion) with 176&nbsp;billion kunas (€23.82&nbsp;billion) worth of imports. Croatia's largest <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">trading partner</a> was the rest of the European Union, with the top three countries being Germany, Italy, and Slovenia.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[188]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">Privatization</a> and the drive towards a <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> had barely begun under the new Croatian Government when war broke out in 1991. As a result of the war, the economic infrastructure sustained massive damage, particularly the revenue-rich tourism industry. From 1989 to 1993, the GDP fell 40.5%. The Croatian state still controls a significant part of the economy, with government expenditures accounting for 40% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-DOS_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DOS-194">[189]</a></sup> A particular concern is a backlogged judiciary system, with inefficient <a href="/wiki/Public_administration" title="Public administration">public administration</a>, especially land ownership and corruption. In the 2018 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>, published by <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>, the country is ranked 60th scoring 48, where zero denotes "highly corrupt" and 100 "very clean".<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[190]</a></sup> At the end of June 2020, the national debt stood at 85,3% of the GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[191]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">Tourism in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG/220px-Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG/330px-Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG/440px-Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG 2x" data-file-width="4272" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dubrovnik_june_2011..JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik" title="Dubrovnik">Dubrovnik</a> is one of Croatia's most popular tourist destinations.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Island_Brac_(20785918360).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg/220px-Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg/330px-Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg/440px-Island_Brac_%2820785918360%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4514" data-file-height="3009"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Island_Brac_(20785918360).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Zlatni_Rat" title="Zlatni Rat">Zlatni Rat</a> beach on the Island of <a href="/wiki/Bra%C4%8D" title="Brač">Brač</a> is one of the foremost spots of <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia" title="Tourism in Croatia">tourism in Croatia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Tourism" title="Tourism">Tourism</a> dominates the Croatian service sector and accounts for up to 20% of Croatian GDP. Tourist industry income for 2019 was estimated to be €10.5&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[192]</a></sup> Its positive effects are felt through the Croatian economy in terms of increased business volume observed in a retail business, processing industry orders and summer seasonal employment. The industry is an export business because it significantly reduces the country's external trade imbalance.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[193]</a></sup> Since the end of the Croatian War of Independence, the tourist industry has rapidly grown, recording a fourfold rise in tourist numbers, with more than 11&nbsp;million tourists each year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia412_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia412-199">[194]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Croatia#Arrivals_by_country" title="Tourism in Croatia">The most numerous</a> are tourists from Germany, Slovenia, Austria, Italy, and Poland as well as Croatia itself.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia415_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia415-200">[195]</a></sup> Length of a tourist stay in Croatia averaged 4.7 days in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[196]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Much of the tourist industry is concentrated along the Adriatic Sea coast. <a href="/wiki/Opatija" title="Opatija">Opatija</a> was the first holiday resort. It first became popular in the middle of the 19th century. By the 1890s, it had become one of the most significant European health resorts.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[197]</a></sup> Later many resorts sprang up along the coast and islands, offering services catering to <a href="/wiki/Mass_tourism" class="mw-redirect" title="Mass tourism">mass tourism</a> and various niche markets. The most significant are <a href="/wiki/Nautical_tourism" title="Nautical tourism">nautical tourism</a>, as there are marinas with more than 16&nbsp;thousand berths, <a href="/wiki/Cultural_tourism" title="Cultural tourism">cultural tourism</a> relying on the appeal of medieval coastal cities and cultural events taking place during the summer. Inland areas offer <a href="/wiki/Agrotourism" class="mw-redirect" title="Agrotourism">agrotourism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mountain_resort" title="Mountain resort">mountain resorts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Spa" title="Spa">spas</a>. Zagreb is also a significant tourist destination, rivalling major coastal cities and resorts.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[198]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia has unpolluted marine areas with nature reserves and 116 <a href="/wiki/Blue_Flag_beach" title="Blue Flag beach">Blue Flag beaches</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[199]</a></sup> Croatia ranks as the 23rd most popular tourist destination in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO-205">[200]</a></sup> About 15% of these visitors, or over one million per year, are involved with <a href="/wiki/Naturism" title="Naturism">naturism</a>, for which Croatia is famous. It was the first European country to develop commercial naturist resorts.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[201]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Croatia" title="Transport in Croatia">Transport in Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Croatia" title="Energy in Croatia">Energy in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2020</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>The highlight of Croatia's recent infrastructure developments is its rapidly developed <a href="/wiki/Motorways_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorways in Croatia">motorway network</a>, largely built in the late 1990s and especially in the 2000s (decade). As of December 2020, Croatia had completed 1,313.8 kilometres (816.4 miles) of motorways, connecting Zagreb to most other regions and following various <a href="/wiki/International_E-road_network" title="International E-road network">European routes</a> and four <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_corridors" title="Pan-European corridors">Pan-European corridors</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-207">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NN-Motorways2009_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NN-Motorways2009-208">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[204]</a></sup> The busiest motorways are the <a href="/wiki/A1_(Croatia)" title="A1 (Croatia)">A1</a>, connecting Zagreb to Split and the <a href="/wiki/A3_(Croatia)" title="A3 (Croatia)">A3</a>, passing east to west through northwest Croatia and Slavonia.<sup id="cite_ref-HC-promet_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HC-promet-210">[205]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kroatien_Autobahnen_(aktueller_Stand).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg/240px-Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="192" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg/360px-Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg/480px-Kroatien_Autobahnen_%28aktueller_Stand%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1402" data-file-height="1123"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kroatien_Autobahnen_(aktueller_Stand).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Highway_network_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Highway network in Croatia">Highway network in Croatia</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A widespread network of <a href="/wiki/State_roads_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="State roads in Croatia">state roads in Croatia</a> acts as motorway <a href="/wiki/Feeder_line_(network)" title="Feeder line (network)">feeder roads</a> while connecting all major settlements. The high quality and safety levels of the Croatian motorway network were tested and confirmed by several EuroTAP and EuroTest programmes.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[206]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[207]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia has an <a href="/wiki/List_of_railways_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of railways in Croatia">extensive rail network</a> spanning 2,722 kilometres (1,691 miles), including 984 kilometres (611 miles) of electrified railways and 254 kilometres (158 miles) of double track railways.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia346_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2013_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia346-213">[208]</a></sup> The most significant railways in Croatia are within the Pan-European transport corridors Vb and X connecting Rijeka to Budapest and Ljubljana to Belgrade, both via Zagreb.<sup id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_207-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-207">[202]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Railways" title="Croatian Railways">Croatian Railways</a> operates all rail services.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[209]</a></sup> There are <a href="/wiki/International_airport" title="International airport">international airports</a> in <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik_Airport" title="Dubrovnik Airport">Dubrovnik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Osijek_Airport" title="Osijek Airport">Osijek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pula_Airport" title="Pula Airport">Pula</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rijeka_Airport" title="Rijeka Airport">Rijeka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Split_Airport" title="Split Airport">Split</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zadar_Airport" title="Zadar Airport">Zadar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Zagreb_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Zagreb International Airport">Zagreb</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MMPI-Airports_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMPI-Airports-215">[210]</a></sup> The largest and busiest is Franjo Tuđman Airport in Zagreb.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[211]</a></sup> As of January&nbsp;2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Croatia complies with <a href="/wiki/International_Civil_Aviation_Organization" title="International Civil Aviation Organization">International Civil Aviation Organization</a> aviation safety standards and the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration" title="Federal Aviation Administration">Federal Aviation Administration</a> upgraded it to Category 1 rating.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The busiest cargo seaport in Croatia is the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Rijeka" title="Port of Rijeka">Port of Rijeka</a>. The busiest passenger ports are <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Split" title="Port of Split">Split</a> and Zadar.<sup id="cite_ref-WB-Rijeka_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WB-Rijeka-218">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMPI-RL-plan_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMPI-RL-plan-219">[214]</a></sup> Many minor ports serve ferries connecting numerous islands and coastal cities with ferry lines to several cities in Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-AOLPP-Rijeka_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AOLPP-Rijeka-220">[215]</a></sup> The largest river port is Vukovar, located on the Danube, representing the nation's outlet to the Pan-European transport corridor VII.<sup id="cite_ref-Helsinki-1997_207-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Helsinki-1997-207">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-MMPI-River-Navigation_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MMPI-River-Navigation-221">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 610 kilometres (380 miles) of crude oil pipelines in Croatia, connecting the Port of Rijeka oil terminal with refineries in Rijeka and Sisak, and several transhipment terminals. The system has a capacity of 20&nbsp;million tonnes per year.<sup id="cite_ref-JANAF-system_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JANAF-system-222">[217]</a></sup> The natural gas transportation system comprises 2,113 kilometres (1,313 miles) of the trunk and regional natural gas pipelines, and more than 300 associated structures, connecting production rigs, the Okoli natural gas storage facility, 27 end-users and 37 distribution systems.<sup id="cite_ref-Plinacro-system_223-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Plinacro-system-223">[218]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatian production of energy sources covers 85% of nationwide natural gas and 19% of oil demand. In 2008, 47.6% of Croatia's primary energy production structure comprised use of natural gas (47.7%), hydropower (25.4%), crude oil (18.0%), fuelwood (8.4%), and other renewable energy sources (0.5%). In 2009, net total electrical power production reached 12,725&nbsp;GWh. Croatia imported 28.5% of its electric power energy needs.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kr%C5%A1ko_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="Krško Nuclear Power Plant">Krško Nuclear Power Plant</a> supplies a large part of Croatian imports, 50% is owned by <a href="/wiki/Hrvatska_elektroprivreda" title="Hrvatska elektroprivreda">Hrvatska elektroprivreda</a>, providing 15% of Croatia's electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-EUB-NEK_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EUB-NEK-224">[219]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><br> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Croatia" title="Demographics of Croatia">Demographics of Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croats" title="Croats">Croats</a>
      </div> 
      <p>With an estimated population of 4.13&nbsp;million in 2019, Croatia <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population">ranks 127th by population</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[220]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">population density</a> stood in 2018 at 72,9 inhabitants per square kilometre, making Croatia one of the more sparsely populated European countries.<sup id="cite_ref-who0_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-who0-226">[221]</a></sup> The overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in Croatia</a> at birth was 76.3 years in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_192-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-192">[187]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="infobox" style="text-align:center; width:97%; margin-right:10px; font-size:90%"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="11">Most populous cities of <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Croatia</a> </th>
        </tr> 
        <tr> 
         <th rowspan="23"><br> <p><a href="/wiki/File:Zagreb_(29255640143).jpg" class="image" title="Zagreb"><img alt="Zagreb" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg/140px-Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="140" height="93" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg/210px-Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg/280px-Zagreb_%2829255640143%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6016" data-file-height="4016"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Zagreb" title="Zagreb">Zagreb</a><br> <a href="/wiki/File:Split_(20897562701).jpg" class="image" title="Split"><img alt="Split" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg/140px-Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="140" height="93" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg/210px-Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg/280px-Split_%2820897562701%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4491" data-file-height="2994"></a><br><a href="/wiki/Split,_Croatia" title="Split, Croatia">Split</a><br> </p> </th>
