      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_Croatia.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Population_density_in_Croatia.png/280px-Population_density_in_Croatia.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="280" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Population_density_in_Croatia.png/420px-Population_density_in_Croatia.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Population_density_in_Croatia.png/560px-Population_density_in_Croatia.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Population_density_in_Croatia.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Population density in Croatia, by <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia" title="Counties of Croatia">county</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> of 1.41 children per mother, is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_fertility_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by fertility rate">lowest in the world</a>, below the replacement rate of 2.1, it remains considerably below the high of 6.18 children born per woman in 1885.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_192-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-192">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[223]</a></sup> Since 1991, Croatia's <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> has continuously exceeded its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> Croatia subsequently has one of the oldest populations in the world, with the average age of 43.3 years.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[224]</a></sup> Since the late 1990s, there has been a positive net migration into Croatia, reaching a level of more than 26,000 net immigrants in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-Limun-immigration_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Limun-immigration-230">[225]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[226]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Bureau_of_Statistics" title="Croatian Bureau of Statistics">Croatian Bureau of Statistics</a> forecast that the population may shrink to 3.85&nbsp;million by 2061, depending on actual birth rate and the level of net migration.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Forecast-2061_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Forecast-2061-232">[227]</a></sup> The population of Croatia rose steadily from 2.1&nbsp;million in 1857 until 1991, when it peaked at 4.7&nbsp;million, with exception of censuses taken in 1921 and 1948, i.e. following two world wars.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> The natural growth rate of the population is currently negative<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_125-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-125">[120]</a></sup> with the <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic transition</a> completed in the 1970s.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[228]</a></sup> In recent years, the Croatian government has been pressured each year to increase permit quotas for foreign workers, reaching an all-time high of 68.100 in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[229]</a></sup> In accordance with its immigration policy, Croatia is trying to entice emigrants to return.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[230]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The population decrease was also a result of the Croatian War of Independence. During the war, large sections of the population were displaced and emigration increased. In 1991, in predominantly occupied areas, more than 400,000 Croats were either removed from their homes by the rebel <a href="/wiki/Serbs_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbs in Croatia">Serb</a> forces or fled the violence.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[231]</a></sup> During the final days of the war in 1995, about 150−200,000 Serbs fled before the arrival of Croatian forces during the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Storm" title="Operation Storm">Operation Storm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc-storm_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-storm-101">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[232]</a></sup> After the war, the number of displaced persons fell to about 250,000. The Croatian government has taken care of displaced persons by the social security system, and since December 1991 through the Office of Displaced Persons and Refugees.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[233]</a></sup> Most of the territories which were abandoned during the Croatian War of Independence were settled by Croat refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina, mostly from north-western Bosnia, while some of the displaced people returned to their homes.<sup id="cite_ref-Index-Cro-Refugees_239-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Index-Cro-Refugees-239">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PresidentRH-refugees_240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PresidentRH-refugees-240">[235]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the 2013 United Nations report, 17.6% of Croatia's population were foreign-born immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[236]</a></sup> Majority of the inhabitants of Croatia are Croats (90.4%), followed by Serbs (4.4%), <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_of_Croatia" title="Bosniaks of Croatia">Bosniaks</a> (0.73%), <a href="/wiki/Italians_of_Croatia" title="Italians of Croatia">Italians</a> (0.42%), <a href="/wiki/Albanians_of_Croatia" title="Albanians of Croatia">Albanians</a> (0.41%), <a href="/wiki/Romani_people_in_Croatia" title="Romani people in Croatia">Roma</a> (0.40%), <a href="/wiki/Hungarians_of_Croatia" title="Hungarians of Croatia">Hungarians</a> (0.33%), <a href="/wiki/Slovenes_of_Croatia" title="Slovenes of Croatia">Slovenes</a> (0.25%), <a href="/wiki/Czechs_of_Croatia" title="Czechs of Croatia">Czechs</a> (0.22%), <a href="/wiki/Montenegrins_of_Croatia" title="Montenegrins of Croatia">Montenegrins</a> (0.11%), <a href="/wiki/Slovaks_of_Croatia" title="Slovaks of Croatia">Slovaks</a> (0.11%), <a href="/wiki/Macedonians_of_Croatia" title="Macedonians of Croatia">Macedonians</a> (0.10%), and others (2.12%).<sup id="cite_ref-Census2011-nationality_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2011-nationality-8">[4]</a></sup> Approximately 4&nbsp;million Croats <a href="/wiki/Croatian_diaspora" title="Croatian diaspora">live abroad</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[237]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Croatia" title="Religion in Croatia">Religion in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:%C5%A0ibenik,_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg/220px-%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg/330px-%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg/440px-%C5%A0ibenik%2C_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5152" data-file-height="3864"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%C5%A0ibenik,_Katedrala_sv._Jakova_-_sjeveroistok.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ibenik_Cathedral" title="Šibenik Cathedral">Cathedral of St. James in Šibenik</a> was included on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Cultural_World_Heritage_List" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO Cultural World Heritage List">UNESCO Cultural World Heritage List</a> in 2000
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has no official religion. <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">Freedom of religion</a> is a right defined by the Constitution which also defines all <a href="/wiki/Religious_denomination" title="Religious denomination">religious communities</a> as <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state" title="Separation of church and state">equal before the law and separated from the state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[238]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the 2011 census, 91.36% of Croatians identify as Christian; of these, Catholics make up the largest group, accounting for 86.28% of the population, after which follows <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodoxy">Eastern Orthodoxy</a> (4.44%), <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> (0.34%), and other Christians (0.30%). The largest religion after Christianity is <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> (1.47%). 4.57% of the population describe themselves as non-religious.<sup id="cite_ref-Census2011-religion_244-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census2011-religion-244">[239]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Eurostat" title="Eurostat">Eurostat</a> Eurobarometer Poll of 2010, 69% of the population of Croatia responded that "they believe there is a God".<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[240]</a></sup> In a 2009 Gallup poll, 70% answered yes to the question "Is religion an important part of your daily life?"<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[241]</a></sup> However, only 24% of the population attends religious services regularly.<sup id="cite_ref-Pew_Survey_2017_-_Final_Topline_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pew_Survey_2017_-_Final_Topline-247">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Languages of Croatia">Languages of Croatia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Minority_languages_of_Croatia" title="Minority languages of Croatia">Minority languages of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a> is the official language of Croatia and became the 24th official language of the European Union upon its accession in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Ustav-RH_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ustav-RH-248">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-VL-Hrvatski-EU_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VL-Hrvatski-EU-249">[244]</a></sup> Minority languages are in official use in local government units where more than a third of the population consists of national minorities or where local legislation defines so. Those languages are <a href="/wiki/Czech_language" title="Czech language">Czech</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_language_in_Croatia" title="Italian language in Croatia">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language_in_Croatia" title="Serbian language in Croatia">Serbian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Franceschini546_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Franceschini546-251">[246]</a></sup> Besides these, the following languages are also recognised: <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_language" title="Bosnian language">Bosnian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">German</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_language" title="Macedonian language">Macedonian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montenegrin_language" title="Montenegrin language">Montenegrin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">Romanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Istro-Romanian_language" title="Istro-Romanian language">Istro-Romanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romani_language" title="Romani language">Romani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rusyn_language" title="Rusyn language">Rusyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovene_language" title="Slovene language">Slovene</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">Turkish</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Franceschini546_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Franceschini546-251">[246]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/280px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png" decoding="async" width="280" height="271" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/420px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png/560px-Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png 2x" data-file-width="620" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Hrvatska_narje%C4%8Dja.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of the dialects of Croatia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to the 2011 Census, 95.6% of citizens of Croatia declared Croatian as their native language, 1.2% declared Serbian as their native language, while no other language is represented in Croatia by more than 0.5% of native speakers among the population of Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-Census-2011-languages_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census-2011-languages-4">[2]</a></sup> Croatian is a member of the <a href="/wiki/South_Slavic_languages" title="South Slavic languages">South Slavic languages</a> of <a href="/wiki/Slavic_languages" title="Slavic languages">Slavic languages</a> group and is written using the <a href="/wiki/Latin_alphabet" title="Latin alphabet">Latin alphabet</a>. There are three major <a href="/wiki/Dialect" title="Dialect">dialects</a> spoken on the territory of Croatia, with standard Croatian based on the <a href="/wiki/Shtokavian_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Shtokavian dialect">Shtokavian dialect</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Chakavian" title="Chakavian">Chakavian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kajkavian" title="Kajkavian">Kajkavian</a> dialects are distinguished by their <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">lexicon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">phonology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syntax" title="Syntax">syntax</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Brozović-HRV_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brozović-HRV-252">[247]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatian replaced <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> as the official language of the Croatian government in the 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-Iadertina-Hr_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Iadertina-Hr-253">[248]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, from 1972 to 1989, the language was constitutionally designated as the "Croatian literary language" and the "Croatian or Serbian language". It was the result of the resistance to "<a href="/wiki/Serbo-Croatian" title="Serbo-Croatian">Serbo-Croatian</a>" in the form of a <a href="/wiki/Declaration_on_the_Status_and_Name_of_the_Croatian_Literary_Language" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language">Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Spring" title="Croatian Spring">Croatian Spring</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[249]</a></sup> Croatians are protective of their language from foreign influences and are known for <a href="/wiki/Croatian_linguistic_purism" title="Croatian linguistic purism">Croatian linguistic purism</a>, as the language was under constant change and threats imposed by previous rulers, i.e. loanwords are replaced with native Croatian counterparts.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A 2011 survey revealed that 78% of Croatians claim knowledge of at least one foreign language.<sup id="cite_ref-Index-lang_256-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Index-lang-256">[251]</a></sup> According to a survey ordered by the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> in 2005, 49% of Croatians speak <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">English</a> as the second language, 34% speak German, 14% speak Italian, and 10% speak <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">French</a>. Russian is spoken by 4% each, and 2% of Croatians speak <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>. However, there are large municipalities <a href="/wiki/Minority_languages_of_Croatia" title="Minority languages of Croatia">that have minority languages</a> that include substantial populations that speak these languages. An odd-majority of Slovenes (59%) have a certain level of knowledge of Croatian.<sup id="cite_ref-EBS-243_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EBS-243-257">[252]</a></sup> The country is a part of various language-based international associations most notably the <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union" title="Languages of the European Union">European Union Language Association.</a><sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[253]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Croatia" title="Education in Croatia">Education in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2020</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:University_of_Zagreb.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/220px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/330px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/University_of_Zagreb.jpg/440px-University_of_Zagreb.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2304" data-file-height="1728"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:University_of_Zagreb.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/University_of_Zagreb" title="University of Zagreb">University of Zagreb</a> is the largest Croatian university and the oldest university in the area covering <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> south of <a href="/wiki/Vienna" title="Vienna">Vienna</a> and all of <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> (1669)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Literacy in Croatia stands at 99.2 per cent.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[254]</a></sup> A worldwide study about the quality of living in different countries published by <i><a href="/wiki/Newsweek" title="Newsweek">Newsweek</a></i> in August 2010 ranked the Croatian education system at 22nd, to share the position with Austria.<sup id="cite_ref-Newsweek-ranking_260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newsweek-ranking-260">[255]</a></sup> Primary education in Croatia starts at the age of six or seven and consists of eight grades. In 2007 a law was passed to increase free, noncompulsory education until 18 years of age. Compulsory education consists of eight grades of elementary school. </p>
      <p>Secondary education is provided by <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">gymnasiums</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vocational_school" title="Vocational school">vocational schools</a>. As of 2019, there are 2,103 elementary schools and 738 schools providing various forms of secondary education.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[256]</a></sup> Primary and secondary education are also available in languages of recognised minorities in Croatia, where classes are held in Czech, German, Hungarian, Italian, and Serbian languages.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia488_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia488-262">[257]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 137 elementary and secondary level <a href="/wiki/Music_school" title="Music school">music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_schools" class="mw-redirect" title="Art schools">art schools</a>, as well as 120 schools for disabled children and youth and 74 schools for adults.<sup id="cite_ref-dzs_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dzs-263">[258]</a></sup> Nationwide <a href="/wiki/Leaving_exams" class="mw-redirect" title="Leaving exams">leaving exams</a> (<a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">državna matura</i>) were introduced for secondary education students in the school year 2009–2010. It comprises three compulsory subjects (Croatian language, mathematics, and a foreign language) and optional subjects and is a prerequisite for university education.<sup id="cite_ref-MZOS-Matura_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MZOS-Matura-264">[259]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg/220px-National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg/330px-National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg/440px-National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4320" data-file-height="3240"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb" title="National and University Library in Zagreb">National and University Library</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has eight public universities, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Dubrovnik" title="University of Dubrovnik">University of Dubrovnik</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Osijek" title="University of Osijek">University of Osijek</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pula" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Pula">University of Pula</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Rijeka" title="University of Rijeka">University of Rijeka</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Split" title="University of Split">University of Split</a>, <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zadar" title="University of Zadar">University of Zadar</a> and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zagreb" title="University of Zagreb">University of Zagreb</a>, and two private universities, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_University_of_Croatia" title="Catholic University of Croatia">Catholic University of Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dubrovnik_International_University" title="Dubrovnik International University">Dubrovnik International University</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-iro_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iro-265">[260]</a></sup> The University of Zadar, the first university in Croatia, was founded in 1396 and remained active until 1807, when other institutions of higher education took over until the foundation of the renewed University of Zadar in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-Zadar-Uni_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zadar-Uni-266">[261]</a></sup> The University of Zagreb, founded in 1669, is the oldest continuously operating university in Southeast Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Zagreb-Uni_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Zagreb-Uni-267">[262]</a></sup> There are also 15 <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology" title="Institute of technology">polytechnics</a>, of which two are private, and 30 higher education institutions, of which 27 are private.<sup id="cite_ref-iro_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iro-265">[260]</a></sup> In total, there are 55 institutions of higher education in Croatia, attended by more than 157&nbsp;thousand students.<sup id="cite_ref-dzs_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dzs-263">[258]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 205 companies, government or education system institutions and non-profit organisations in Croatia pursuing scientific research and development of technology. Combined, they spent more than 3&nbsp;billion kuna (€400&nbsp;million) and employed 10,191 full-time research staff in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> Among the scientific institutes operating in Croatia, the largest is the <a href="/wiki/Ru%C4%91er_Bo%C5%A1kovi%C4%87_Institute" title="Ruđer Bošković Institute">Ruđer Bošković Institute</a> in Zagreb.<sup id="cite_ref-JL-IRB_268-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-IRB-268">[263]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts">Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts</a> in Zagreb is a <a href="/wiki/Learned_society" title="Learned society">learned society</a> promoting language, culture, arts and science from its inception in 1866.<sup id="cite_ref-HAZU-founding_269-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HAZU-founding-269">[264]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia has been the home of many <a href="/wiki/Category:Croatian_inventors" title="Category:Croatian inventors">famous inventors</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Faust_Vran%C4%8Di%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Faust Vrančić">Faust Vrančić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_Luppis" title="Giovanni Luppis">Giovanni Luppis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slavoljub_Eduard_Penkala" title="Slavoljub Eduard Penkala">Slavoljub Eduard Penkala</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franjo_Hanaman" title="Franjo Hanaman">Franjo Hanaman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Josip_Belu%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Josip Belušić">Josip Belušić</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla" title="Nikola Tesla">Nikola Tesla</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[267]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Category:Croatian_scientists" title="Category:Croatian scientists">scientists</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Franciscus_Patricius" title="Franciscus Patricius">Franciscus Patricius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Nalje%C5%A1kovi%C4%87" title="Nikola Nalješković">Nikola Nalješković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Vitov_Gu%C4%8Deti%C4%87" title="Nikola Vitov Gučetić">Nikola Vitov Gučetić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Josip_Franjo_Domin" title="Josip Franjo Domin">Josip Franjo Domin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marin_Getaldi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Marin Getaldić">Marin Getaldić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roger_Joseph_Boscovich" title="Roger Joseph Boscovich">Roger Joseph Boscovich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrija_Mohorovi%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Andrija Mohorovičić">Andrija Mohorovičić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Supek" title="Ivan Supek">Ivan Supek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_%C4%90iki%C4%87" title="Ivan Đikić">Ivan Đikić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Radman" title="Miroslav Radman">Miroslav Radman</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marin_Solja%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Marin Soljačić">Marin Soljačić</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[268]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> has been awarded to two Croatian laureates, <a href="/wiki/Lavoslav_Ru%C5%BEi%C4%8Dka" class="mw-redirect" title="Lavoslav Ružička">Lavoslav Ružička</a> (1939) and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Prelog" title="Vladimir Prelog">Vladimir Prelog</a> (1975). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Croatia" title="Healthcare in Croatia">Healthcare in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/220px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/330px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg/440px-KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg 2x" data-file-width="751" data-file-height="530"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KBC_Rebro_aerial.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/University_Hospital_Centre_Zagreb" title="University Hospital Centre Zagreb">University Hospital Centre Zagreb</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatia has a <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system, whose roots can be traced back to the Hungarian-Croatian Parliament Act of 1891, providing a form of mandatory insurance of all factory workers and craftsmen.<sup id="cite_ref-RSP-1891_274-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RSP-1891-274">[269]</a></sup> The population is covered by a basic health insurance plan provided by statute and optional insurance. In 2017, annual healthcare related expenditures reached 22.0&nbsp;billion kuna (€3.0&nbsp;billion).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia549_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia549-275">[270]</a></sup> Healthcare expenditures comprise only 0.6% of private health insurance and public spending.<sup id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-Zdravstvo_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-Zdravstvo-276">[271]</a></sup> In 2017, Croatia spent around 6.6% of its GDP on healthcare.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[272]</a></sup> In 2020, Croatia ranked 41st in the world in life expectancy with 76.0 years for men and 82.0 years for women, and it had a low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a> of 3.4 per 1,000 <a href="/wiki/Live_birth_(human)" title="Live birth (human)">live births</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[273]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are hundreds of healthcare institutions in Croatia, including 75 hospitals, and 13 clinics with 23,049 beds. The hospitals and clinics care for more than 700&nbsp;thousand patients per year and employ 6,642 <a href="/wiki/Medical_doctors" class="mw-redirect" title="Medical doctors">medical doctors</a>, including 4,773 specialists. There is total of 69,841&nbsp;health workers in the country. There are 119 emergency units in health centres, responding to more than a million calls. The principal cause of death in 2016 was <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a> at 39.7% for men and 50.1% for women, followed by tumours, at 32.5% for men and 23.4% for women.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[274]</a></sup> In 2020, 69 Croatians had been infected with HIV/AIDS and 11 had died from the disease.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[275]</a></sup> In 2016 it was estimated that 37.0% of Croatians are smokers.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[276]</a></sup> According to 2016 data, 24.40% of the Croatian adult population is obese.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[277]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia" title="Culture of Croatia">Culture of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites in Croatia">World Heritage Sites in Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Register_of_Cultural_Goods_of_Croatia" title="Register of Cultural Goods of Croatia">Register of Cultural Goods of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:TrogirView.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TrogirView.jpg/220px-TrogirView.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TrogirView.jpg/330px-TrogirView.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/TrogirView.jpg/440px-TrogirView.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="2134"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:TrogirView.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Historic centre of <a href="/wiki/Trogir" title="Trogir">Trogir</a> has been included in the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> list of <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a> since 1997<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[278]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Because of its geographical position, Croatia represents a blend of four different cultural spheres. It has been a crossroads of influences from western culture and the east since the schism between the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, and also from <a href="/wiki/Mitteleuropa" title="Mitteleuropa">Mitteleuropa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Mediterranean culture">Mediterranean culture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HTZ-History-Culture_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HTZ-History-Culture-284">[279]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_movement" title="Illyrian movement">Illyrian movement</a> was the most significant period of national cultural history, as the 19th century proved crucial to the emancipation of the Croatian language and saw unprecedented developments in all fields of art and culture, giving rise to many <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Croatia#People" title="Culture of Croatia">historical figures</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-CRIS-Stančić_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CRIS-Stančić-52">[47]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Culture_(Croatia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Culture (Croatia)">Ministry of Culture</a> is tasked with preserving the nation's <a href="/wiki/Natural_and_Cultural_Heritage_of_Croatia" title="Natural and Cultural Heritage of Croatia">cultural and natural heritage</a> and overseeing its development. Further activities supporting the development of culture are undertaken at the local government level.<sup id="cite_ref-MKult-Djelokrug_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MKult-Djelokrug-285">[280]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_by_country" title="World Heritage Sites by country">World Heritage List</a> includes <a href="/wiki/Ten_sites_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Ten sites in Croatia">ten sites in Croatia</a>. The country is also rich with <a href="/wiki/Intangible_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Intangible culture">intangible culture</a> and holds 15 of <a href="/wiki/UNESCO%27s_World%27s_intangible_culture_masterpieces" class="mw-redirect" title="UNESCO's World's intangible culture masterpieces">UNESCO's World's intangible culture masterpieces</a>, ranking fourth in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[281]</a></sup> A global cultural contribution from Croatia is the necktie, derived from the <a href="/wiki/Cravat" title="Cravat">cravat</a> originally worn by the 17th-century Croatian mercenaries in France.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT-tie_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-tie-287">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Huzjan_288-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Huzjan-288">[283]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/220px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/330px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG/440px-Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_2007.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Trako%C5%A1%C4%87an_Castle" title="Trakošćan Castle">Trakošćan Castle</a> is one of the best preserved historic buildings in the country<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[284]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2019, Croatia had 95 professional theatres, 30 professional children's theatres, and 51 amateur theatres visited by more than 2.27&nbsp;million viewers per year. Professional theatres employ 1,195 artists. There are 42 professional orchestras, ensembles, and choirs in the country, attracting an annual attendance of 297&nbsp;thousand. There are 75 cinemas with 166 screens and attendance of 5.026&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2018_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia512–513_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2018_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia512–513-290">[285]</a></sup> Croatia has 222 museums, visited by more than 2.71&nbsp;million people in 2016. Furthermore, there are 1,768 libraries in the country, containing 26.8&nbsp;million volumes, and 19 state archives.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia520-521_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE2017_Statistical_Yearbook_of_the_Republic_of_Croatia520-521-291">[286]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010, 7,348 books and brochures were published, along with 2,676 magazines and 267 newspapers.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title=" (January 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> In 2019, there were 134 radio stations and 26 TV stations operating. Film production made 75 films, 12 were feature-length films and 63 short films. As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are 784 amateur cultural and artistic associations<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title=" (January 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup> and more than 10&nbsp;thousand cultural, educational, and artistic events held annually.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> The book publishing market is dominated by several major publishers and the industry's centrepiece event—<a href="/wiki/Interliber" title="Interliber">Interliber</a> exhibition held annually at <a href="/wiki/Zagreb_Fair" title="Zagreb Fair">Zagreb Fair</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-JL-Interliber_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-Interliber-292">[287]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Croatia is categorised as having established a very high level of human development in the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>, with a high degree of equality in HDI achievements between women and men.<sup id="cite_ref-HDI_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-293">[288]</a></sup> It promotes <a href="/wiki/Disability_rights_movement" title="Disability rights movement">disability rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-EU-Disability_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU-Disability-294">[289]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Recognition_of_same-sex_unions_in_Croatia" title="Recognition of same-sex unions in Croatia">Recognition of same-sex unions in Croatia</a> has gradually improved over the past decade, culminating in registered <a href="/wiki/Civil_unions" class="mw-redirect" title="Civil unions">civil unions</a> in July 2014, granting same-sex couples equal inheritance rights, tax deductions, and limited adoption rights.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[290]</a></sup> However, in December 2013 Croatians voted in a <a href="/wiki/2013_Croatian_constitutional_referendum" title="2013 Croatian constitutional referendum">constitutional referendum</a> and approved changes to the constitution to define marriage as a union between a man and a woman.<sup id="cite_ref-gay_marriage_reuters_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gay_marriage_reuters-296">[291]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Arts.2C_literature.2C_and_music"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts,_literature,_and_music">Arts, literature, and music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Croatian_art" title="Croatian art">Croatian art</a>, <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Croatia" title="Architecture of Croatia">Architecture of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_literature" title="Croatian literature">Croatian literature</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian music">Croatian music</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Anfiteatro_de_Pula,_Croacia,_2017-04-17,_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg/220px-Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg/330px-Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg/440px-Anfiteatro_de_Pula%2C_Croacia%2C_2017-04-17%2C_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg 2x" data-file-width="7734" data-file-height="4773"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Anfiteatro_de_Pula,_Croacia,_2017-04-17,_DD_58-63_HDR_PAN.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The 1st century-built <a href="/wiki/Pula_Arena" title="Pula Arena">Pula Arena</a> was the sixth largest <a href="/wiki/Amphitheatre" title="Amphitheatre">amphitheatre</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Architecture in Croatia reflects influences of bordering nations. Austrian and Hungarian influence is visible in public spaces and buildings in the north and the central regions, architecture found along coasts of Dalmatia and Istria exhibits Venetian influence.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[292]</a></sup> Squares named after culture heroes, parks, and pedestrian-only zones, are features of Croatian towns and cities, especially where large scale <a href="/wiki/Baroque_architecture" title="Baroque architecture">Baroque</a> urban planning took place, for instance in Osijek (<a href="/wiki/Tvr%C4%91a" title="Tvrđa">Tvrđa</a>), Varaždin, and Karlovac.<sup id="cite_ref-Telegraph-Baroque_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Telegraph-Baroque-298">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JL-Karlovac-Baroque_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-Karlovac-Baroque-299">[294]</a></sup> The subsequent influence of the <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> was reflected in contemporary architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-IPU-Art-Nouveau_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IPU-Art-Nouveau-300">[295]</a></sup> The architecture is the Mediterranean with a Venetian and Renaissance influence in major coastal urban areas exemplified in works of <a href="/wiki/Juraj_Dalmatinac" class="mw-redirect" title="Juraj Dalmatinac">Juraj Dalmatinac</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nicolas_of_Florence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nicolas of Florence (page does not exist)">Nicolas of Florence</a> such as the <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ibenik_Cathedral" title="Šibenik Cathedral">Cathedral of St. James</a> in Šibenik. The oldest preserved examples of Croatian architecture are the 9th-century churches, with the largest and the most representative among them being <a href="/wiki/Church_of_St._Donatus" class="mw-redirect" title="Church of St. Donatus">Church of St. Donatus</a> in <a href="/wiki/Zadar" title="Zadar">Zadar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Art_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Art-301">[296]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TZZadar-Donat_302-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TZZadar-Donat-302">[297]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Peristyle,_Split_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg/220px-Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg/330px-Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg/440px-Peristyle%2C_Split_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="683"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Peristyle,_Split_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Historical nucleus of <a href="/wiki/Split,_Croatia" title="Split, Croatia">Split</a> with the 4th-century <a href="/wiki/Diocletian%27s_Palace" title="Diocletian's Palace">Diocletian's Palace</a> was inscribed on the <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> list of <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> in 1979
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Besides the architecture encompassing the oldest artworks, there is a history of artists in Croatia reaching the Middle Ages. In that period the stone portal of the <a href="/wiki/Trogir_Cathedral" title="Trogir Cathedral">Trogir Cathedral</a> was made by <a href="/wiki/Radovan_(master)" title="Radovan (master)">Radovan</a>, representing the most important monument of <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">Romanesque</a> sculpture from <a href="/wiki/Croatia_in_the_union_with_Hungary" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatia in the union with Hungary">Medieval Croatia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_in_Croatia" title="Renaissance in Croatia">Renaissance</a> had the greatest impact on the Adriatic Sea coast since the remainder of Croatia was embroiled in the Hundred Years' Croatian–Ottoman War. With the waning of the Ottoman Empire, art flourished during the <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">Rococo</a>. The 19th and the 20th centuries brought about affirmation of numerous Croatian artisans, helped by several patrons of the arts such as bishop <a href="/wiki/Josip_Juraj_Strossmayer" title="Josip Juraj Strossmayer">Josip Juraj Strossmayer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Essehist-Strossmayer_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Essehist-Strossmayer-303">[298]</a></sup> Croatian artists of the period achieving renown were <a href="/wiki/Vlaho_Bukovac" title="Vlaho Bukovac">Vlaho Bukovac</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87" title="Ivan Meštrović">Ivan Meštrović</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MVPEI-Art_301-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MVPEI-Art-301">[296]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Baška tablet, a stone inscribed with the <a href="/wiki/Glagolitic_alphabet" class="mw-redirect" title="Glagolitic alphabet">glagolitic alphabet</a> found on the Krk island and dated to circa 1100, is considered to be the oldest surviving prose in Croatian.<sup id="cite_ref-KRK-Baška_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-KRK-Baška-304">[299]</a></sup> The beginning of more vigorous development of Croatian literature is marked by the Renaissance and <a href="/wiki/Marko_Maruli%C4%87" title="Marko Marulić">Marko Marulić</a>. Besides Marulić, Renaissance playwright <a href="/wiki/Marin_Dr%C5%BEi%C4%87" title="Marin Držić">Marin Držić</a>, Baroque poet <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Gunduli%C4%87" title="Ivan Gundulić">Ivan Gundulić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_national_revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian national revival">Croatian national revival</a> poet <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Ma%C5%BEurani%C4%87" title="Ivan Mažuranić">Ivan Mažuranić</a>, novelist, playwright, and poet <a href="/wiki/August_%C5%A0enoa" title="August Šenoa">August Šenoa</a>, children's writer <a href="/wiki/Ivana_Brli%C4%87-Ma%C5%BEurani%C4%87" title="Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić">Ivana Brlić-Mažuranić</a>, writer and journalist <a href="/wiki/Marija_Juri%C4%87_Zagorka" title="Marija Jurić Zagorka">Marija Jurić Zagorka</a>, poet and writer <a href="/wiki/Antun_Gustav_Mato%C5%A1" title="Antun Gustav Matoš">Antun Gustav Matoš</a>, poet <a href="/wiki/Antun_Branko_%C5%A0imi%C4%87" title="Antun Branko Šimić">Antun Branko Šimić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Expressionist" class="mw-redirect" title="Expressionist">expressionist</a> and <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">realist</a> writer <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Krle%C5%BEa" title="Miroslav Krleža">Miroslav Krleža</a>, poet <a href="/wiki/Tin_Ujevi%C4%87" title="Tin Ujević">Tin Ujević</a> and novelist, and short story writer <a href="/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87" title="Ivo Andrić">Ivo Andrić</a> are often cited as the greatest figures in Croatian literature.<sup id="cite_ref-LZMK_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LZMK-305">[300]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT-Readerguide_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-Readerguide-306">[301]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Croatia">Media of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Croatia" title="Cinema of Croatia">Cinema of Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Croatia" title="Television in Croatia">Television in Croatia</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Radio_stations_in_Croatia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Radio stations in Croatia (page does not exist)">Radio stations in Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Matica,_ljudevit_gaj.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg/170px-Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg/255px-Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg/340px-Matica%2C_ljudevit_gaj.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="993"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Matica,_ljudevit_gaj.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ljudevit_Gaj" title="Ljudevit Gaj">Ljudevit Gaj</a>, Croatian linguist, politician, journalist and writer. He was one of the central figures of the <a href="/wiki/Pan-Slavist" class="mw-redirect" title="Pan-Slavist">pan-Slavist</a> <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_Movement" class="mw-redirect" title="Illyrian Movement">Illyrian Movement</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In Croatia, the Constitution guarantees the freedom of the press and the freedom of speech.<sup id="cite_ref-worldpress_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldpress-307">[302]</a></sup> Croatia ranked 64th in the 2019 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> report compiled by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> which noted that journalists who investigate corruption, organised crime or war crimes face challenges and that the Government was trying to influence the public broadcaster <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">HRT</a>'s editorial policies.<sup id="cite_ref-index_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-index-308">[303]</a></sup> In its 2019 Freedom in the World report, the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> classified freedoms of press and speech in Croatia as generally free from political interference and manipulation, noting that journalists still face threats and occasional attacks.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[304]</a></sup> The state-owned news agency <a href="/wiki/HINA" class="mw-redirect" title="HINA">HINA</a> runs a <a href="/wiki/Wire_service" class="mw-redirect" title="Wire service">wire service</a> in Croatian and English on politics, economics, society, and culture.<sup id="cite_ref-HINA-about_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HINA-about-310">[305]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As of January&nbsp;2021<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Croatia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are thirteen nationwide free-to-air <a href="/wiki/DVB-T" title="DVB-T">DVB-T</a> television channels, with <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">Croatian Radiotelevision</a> (HRT) operating four, <a href="/wiki/RTL_(Croatian_TV_channel)" title="RTL (Croatian TV channel)">RTL Televizija</a> three, and <a href="/wiki/Nova_TV_(Croatia)" title="Nova TV (Croatia)">Nova TV</a> operating two channels, and the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Olympic_Committee" title="Croatian Olympic Committee">Croatian Olympic Committee</a>, Kapital Net d.o.o., and Author d.o.o. companies operate the remaining three.<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[306]</a></sup> Also, there are 21 regional or local DVB-T television channels.<sup id="cite_ref-OIV-DVBT_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OIV-DVBT-312">[307]</a></sup> The HRT is also broadcasting a satellite TV channel.<sup id="cite_ref-HRT-Sat_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRT-Sat-313">[308]</a></sup> In 2020, there were 155 radio stations and 27 TV stations in Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-dzs2_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dzs2-314">[309]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[310]</a></sup> Cable television and <a href="/wiki/IPTV" class="mw-redirect" title="IPTV">IPTV</a> networks are gaining ground in the country. Cable television already serves 450&nbsp;thousand people, around 10% of the total population of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-Lider-IPTV_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lider-IPTV-316">[311]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-JL-cableTV_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-cableTV-317">[312]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/220px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="106" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/330px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg/440px-Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1201" data-file-height="580"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_HRT_Zagreb.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radio" title="Croatian Radio">Radio Zagreb</a>, now a part of <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Radiotelevision" class="mw-redirect" title="Croatian Radiotelevision">Croatian Radiotelevision</a>, was the first public radio station in Southeast Europe<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[313]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2010, 314 newspapers and 2,678 magazines were published in Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> The print media market is dominated by the Croatian-owned <a href="/wiki/Hanza_Media" title="Hanza Media">Hanza Media</a> and Austrian-owned <a href="/wiki/Styria_Media_Group" title="Styria Media Group">Styria Media Group</a> who publish their flagship dailies <i><a href="/wiki/Jutarnji_list" title="Jutarnji list">Jutarnji list</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Ve%C4%8Dernji_list" title="Večernji list">Večernji list</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/24sata_(Croatia)" title="24sata (Croatia)">24sata</a></i>. Other influential newspapers are <i><a href="/wiki/Novi_list" title="Novi list">Novi list</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Slobodna_Dalmacija" title="Slobodna Dalmacija">Slobodna Dalmacija</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-EPH-Print_319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EPH-Print-319">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Styria-dailies_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Styria-dailies-320">[315]</a></sup> In 2020, <i>24sata</i> was the most widely circulated daily newspaper, followed by <i>Večernji list</i> and <i>Jutarnji list</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[317]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Croatia%27s_film_industry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Croatia's film industry (page does not exist)">Croatia's film industry</a> is small and heavily subsidised by the government, mainly through grants approved by the Ministry of Culture with films often being co-produced by HRT.<sup id="cite_ref-JL-Film_323-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JL-Film-323">[318]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-HRT-coproducing_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRT-coproducing-324">[319]</a></sup> Croatian cinema produces between five and ten feature films per year.<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[320]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pula_Film_Festival" title="Pula Film Festival">Pula Film Festival</a>, the national film awards event held annually in <a href="/wiki/Pula" title="Pula">Pula</a>, is the most prestigious film event featuring national and international productions.<sup id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-PulaFilm_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-PulaFilm-326">[321]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Animafest_Zagreb" title="Animafest Zagreb">Animafest Zagreb</a>, founded in 1972, is the prestigious annual film festival dedicated to the animated film. The first greatest accomplishment by Croatian filmmakers was achieved by <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Vukoti%C4%87" title="Dušan Vukotić">Dušan Vukotić</a> when he won the 1961 <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film" title="Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film">Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Surogat" title="Surogat">Ersatz</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">Surogat</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-Vjesnik-surogat_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vjesnik-surogat-327">[322]</a></sup> Croatian film producer <a href="/wiki/Branko_Lustig" title="Branko Lustig">Branko Lustig</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture" title="Academy Award for Best Picture">Academy Awards for Best Picture</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Schindler%27s_List" title="Schindler's List">Schindler's List</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Gladiator_(2000_film)" title="Gladiator (2000 film)">Gladiator</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Film_Producer_Branko_Lustig_Becomes_Honorary_Citizen_of_Zagreb_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Film_Producer_Branko_Lustig_Becomes_Honorary_Citizen_of_Zagreb-328">[323]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Croatian_cuisine" title="Croatian cuisine">Croatian cuisine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatian_wine" title="Croatian wine">Croatian wine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Vino_Teran_(Croatia).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg/220px-Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg/330px-Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg/440px-Vino_Teran_%28Croatia%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Vino_Teran_(Croatia).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Teran_wine" class="mw-redirect" title="Teran wine">Teran wine</a> from <a href="/wiki/Istria_County" title="Istria County">Istria County</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatian traditional cuisine varies from one region to another. Dalmatia and Istria have culinary influences of <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">Italian</a> and other <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_cuisine" title="Mediterranean cuisine">Mediterranean cuisines</a> which prominently feature various seafood, cooked vegetables and pasta, and condiments such as olive oil and garlic. <a href="/wiki/Austrian_cuisine" title="Austrian cuisine">Austrian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine" title="Hungarian cuisine">Hungarian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish</a> culinary styles influenced continental cuisine. In that area, meats, freshwater fish, and vegetable dishes are predominant.<sup id="cite_ref-HTZ-cuisine_329-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HTZ-cuisine-329">[324]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are two distinct wine-producing regions in Croatia. The continental in the northeast of the country, especially Slavonia, produces premium wines, particularly whites. Along the north coast, Istrian and Krk wines are similar to those in neighbouring Italy, while further south in Dalmatia, Mediterranean-style red wines are the norm.<sup id="cite_ref-HTZ-cuisine_329-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HTZ-cuisine-329">[324]</a></sup> Annual production of wine exceeds 140&nbsp;million litres.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> Croatia was almost exclusively a wine-consuming country up until the late 18th century when a more massive production and beer consumption started.<sup id="cite_ref-skenderovic_330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-skenderovic-330">[325]</a></sup> The annual consumption of beer in 2020 was 78.7 litres per capita which placed Croatia in 15th place among the world's countries.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[326]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Croatia" title="Sport in Croatia">Sport in Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Croatia_at_the_Olympics" title="Croatia at the Olympics">Croatia at the Olympics</a>
      </div> 
      <table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Ambox current red Americas.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png" decoding="async" width="42" height="34" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="360" data-file-height="290">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2021</span>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>There are more than 400,000 active sportspeople in Croatia.<sup id="cite_ref-Perman-400_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perman-400-332">[327]</a></sup> Out of that number, 277,000 are members of sports associations and nearly 4,000 are chess members and <a href="/wiki/Contract_bridge" title="Contract bridge">contract bridge</a> associations.<sup id="cite_ref-DZS-Stat2010_124-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DZS-Stat2010-124">[119]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> is the most popular sport. The <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Football_Federation" title="Croatian Football Federation">Croatian Football Federation</a> (<a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">Hrvatski nogometni savez</i>), with more than 118,000 registered players, is the largest sporting association in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-CFF-members_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CFF-members-333">[328]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Prva_HNL" class="mw-redirect" title="Prva HNL">Prva HNL</a> football league attracts the highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_sports_attendance_figures" title="List of sports attendance figures">average attendance</a> of any professional sports league in the country. In <a href="/wiki/2010%E2%80%9311_Prva_HNL" class="mw-redirect" title="2010–11 Prva HNL">season 2010–11</a>, it attracted 458,746 spectators.<sup id="cite_ref-Index-attendance_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Index-attendance-334">[329]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg/280px-Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg" decoding="async" width="280" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg/420px-Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg/560px-Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Croatia_WC2018_final.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team" title="Croatia national football team">Croatia national football team</a> came in second at the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 World Cup</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Croatian athletes competing at international events since Croatian independence in 1991 won 44 <a href="/wiki/Croatia_at_the_Olympics" title="Croatia at the Olympics">Olympic medals</a>, including 15 gold medals—at the <a href="/wiki/1996_Summer_Olympics" title="1996 Summer Olympics">1996</a> and <a href="/wiki/2004_Summer_Olympics" title="2004 Summer Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">handball</a>, <a href="/wiki/2000_Summer_Olympics" title="2000 Summer Olympics">2000 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting" title="Olympic weightlifting">weightlifting</a>, <a href="/wiki/2002_Winter_Olympics" title="2002 Winter Olympics">2002</a> and <a href="/wiki/2006_Winter_Olympics" title="2006 Winter Olympics">2006 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Alpine_skiing" title="Alpine skiing">alpine skiing</a>, <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw" title="Discus throw">discus throw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trap_shooting" title="Trap shooting">trap shooting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">water polo</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Shooting_sport" class="mw-redirect" title="Shooting sport">shooting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Discus_throw_at_the_Olympics" title="Discus throw at the Olympics">discus throw</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sailing_(sport)" title="Sailing (sport)">sailing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Javelin_throw_at_the_Olympics" title="Javelin throw at the Olympics">javelin throw</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HOO-medalists_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HOO-medalists-335">[330]</a></sup> Also, Croatian athletes won 16 gold medals at world championships, including four in athletics at the World Championships in Athletics, held in <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2007 World Championships in Athletics">2007</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2009 World Championships in Athletics">2009</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2013 World Championships in Athletics">2013</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017_World_Championships_in_Athletics" title="2017 World Championships in Athletics">2017</a>, one in handball at the <a href="/wiki/2003_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2003 World Men's Handball Championship">2003 World Men's Handball Championship</a>, two in water polo at the <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="2007 World Aquatics Championships">2007 World Aquatics Championships</a> and <a href="/wiki/Water_polo_at_the_2017_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="Water polo at the 2017 World Aquatics Championships">2017 World Aquatics Championships</a>, one in rowing at the <a href="/wiki/2010_World_Rowing_Championships" title="2010 World Rowing Championships">2010 World Rowing Championships</a>, six in alpine skiing at the <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2003" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2003">FIS Alpine World Ski Championships held in 2003</a> and <a href="/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships_2005" title="FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2005">2005</a> and two at the World Taekwondo Championships in <a href="/wiki/2011_World_Taekwondo_Championships" title="2011 World Taekwondo Championships">2011</a> and <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Taekwondo_Championships" title="2007 World Taekwondo Championships">2007</a>. In tennis, Croatia won <a href="/wiki/Davis_Cup" title="Davis Cup">Davis Cup</a> in <a href="/wiki/2005_Davis_Cup" title="2005 Davis Cup">2005</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_Davis_Cup" title="2018 Davis Cup">2018</a>. Croatia's most successful male players <a href="/wiki/Goran_Ivani%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Goran Ivanišević">Goran Ivanišević</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marin_%C4%8Cili%C4%87" title="Marin Čilić">Marin Čilić</a> have both won <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> titles and have got into the top 3 of the <a href="/wiki/ATP_Rankings" title="ATP Rankings">ATP Rankings</a>. Iva Majoli became the first Croatian female player to win the <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a> when she won it in <a href="/wiki/1997_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1997 French Open – Women's Singles">1997</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team" title="Croatia national football team">Croatian national football team</a> came in third in <a href="/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1998 FIFA World Cup">1998</a> and second in the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>. Croatia hosted several major sports competitions, including the <a href="/wiki/2009_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2009 World Men's Handball Championship">2009 World Men's Handball Championship</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2007_World_Table_Tennis_Championships" title="2007 World Table Tennis Championships">2007 World Table Tennis Championships</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2000_World_Rowing_Championships" title="2000 World Rowing Championships">2000 World Rowing Championships</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1987_Summer_Universiade" title="1987 Summer Universiade">1987 Summer Universiade</a>, the <a href="/wiki/1979_Mediterranean_Games" title="1979 Mediterranean Games">1979 Mediterranean Games</a>, and several <a href="/wiki/European_Championship" title="European Championship">European Championships</a>. </p>
      <p>The governing sports authority in the country is the <a href="/wiki/Croatian_Olympic_Committee" title="Croatian Olympic Committee">Croatian Olympic Committee</a> (<a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>: <i lang="hr">Hrvatski olimpijski odbor</i>), founded on 10 September 1991 and recognised by the <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> since 17 January 1992, in time to permit the Croatian athletes to appear at the <a href="/wiki/1992_Winter_Olympics" title="1992 Winter Olympics">1992 Winter Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Albertville" title="Albertville">Albertville</a>, France representing the newly independent nation for the first time at the <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic Games</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HOO-COO_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HOO-COO-336">[331]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
